    Development of Potential Antitumor Agents from the Scaffolds of Plant-Derived Terpenoid Lactones

    • Yulin Ren*
      Yulin Ren
      Division of Medicinal Chemistry and Pharmacognosy, College of Pharmacy, The Ohio State University, Columbus, Ohio 43210, United States
      *Phone: 1-(740) 707-1263. Email: [email protected]. Fax: (614) 247-8094.
      More by Yulin Ren
      View Biography
      http://orcid.org/0000-0003-3667-1466
      •  and 
    • A. Douglas Kinghorn*
      A. Douglas Kinghorn
      Division of Medicinal Chemistry and Pharmacognosy, College of Pharmacy, The Ohio State University, Columbus, Ohio 43210, United States
      *Phone: 1(614) 247-8094. Email: [email protected]. Fax: (614) 247-8094.
      More by A. Douglas Kinghorn
      View Biography
      http://orcid.org/0000-0002-6647-8707
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2020, 63, 24, 15410–15448
    Publication Date (Web):December 8, 2020

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Naturally occurring terpenoid lactones and their synthetic derivatives have attracted increasing interest for their promising antitumor activity and potential utilization in the discovery and design of new antitumor agents. In the present perspective article, selected plant-derived five-membered γ-lactones and six-membered δ-lactones that occur with terpenoid scaffolds are reviewed, with their structures, cancer cell line cytotoxicity and in vivo antitumor activity, structure–activity relationships, mechanism of action, and the potential for developing cancer chemotherapeutic agents discussed in each case. The compounds presented include artemisinin (ART, 1), parthenolide (PTL, 2), thapsigargin (TPG, 3), andrographolide (AGL, 4), ginkgolide B (GKL B, 5), jolkinolide B (JKL B, 6), nagilactone E (NGL E, 7), triptolide (TPL, 8), bruceantin (BRC, 9), dichapetalin A (DCT A, 10), and limonin (LMN, 11), and their naturally occurring analogues and synthetic derivatives. It is hoped that this contribution will be supportive of the future development of additional efficacious anticancer agents derived from natural products.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Cancer results from an abnormally excessive growth of tissue or a neoplasia, and develops through the stages of carcinoma in situ, invasion, angiogenesis, and metastasis. Cancer may be characterized by all of aggressive cellular growth, relapse, metastasis, and resistance to existing cancer chemotherapeutic agents, and thus is one of the most serious diseases known.(1) In addition, cancer is a genetic disease, with a mutator phenotype found ubiquitously in cancer cells. The repair of DNA damage becomes skewed in cancer cells, which results in multiple mutations, and the genome of cancer cells is unstable, leading to cascades of mutations and then the development of tumor resistance to drug therapy.(2) Thus, theoretically, drugs that are directed to cancer cells, DNA, or tumor genomes may not be totally effective in treating cancer, so it seems preferable that further anticancer drug design should focus on lead compounds with multiple molecular targets.
    Many currently available cancer chemotherapy regimens are insufficient for treating cancer, and several problems, including the occurrence of adverse effects and the development of multidrug resistance (MDR), have been observed with their use in cancer clinics. For more than 50 years, natural products (NPs) have played a key role in the discovery of anticancer agents, as evidenced by the increasing numbers of new anticancer drugs that are developed from diverse natural sources. These naturally derived drugs mediate their activity through different cellular mechanisms, of which some are novel or unusual, and thus, developing promising agents from NPs to treat cancer effectively has become well accepted.(3−5)
    The natural terpenoids are derived from five-carbon (C5) units of isoprene (2-methyl-1,3-butadiene) via “head-to-head” or “head-to-tail” addition and are characterized mainly as monoterpene (C10), sesquiterpene (C15), diterpene (C20), and triterpene (C30) subgroups, based on the number of C5 isoprene units contained. These NPs are involved in various cellular processes and have a number of biotechnological applications.(6,7) As plant-signaling hormones, terpenoids show important physiological properties,(8) and they also exhibit a broad range of the biological activities that may benefit human health, including having antitumor, antimicrobial, antifungal, antiviral, antihyperglycemic, antiinflammatory, and antiparasitic properties.(9) Of these compounds, natural terpene lactones (NTLs) are a large group, with a γ-lactone (five-membered tetrahydrofuran ring system) or a δ-lactone (six-membered tetrahydropyran ring system) occurring commonly in different types of terpenoids. NTLs exhibit a variety of potent biological activities, as described recently in an extensive review on sesquiterpene lactones in 2018,(10) as well as in several of our laboratory contributions on goyazensolides (SQLs) in 2016 and on dichapetalins (triterpene lactones) in 2018 and 2019.(11−13)
    As an extension of the previous literature, in the present perspective, selected plant-derived terpenoids that contain either a five-membered γ-lactone or a six-membered δ-lactone unit and development work toward their possible utilization in cancer chemotherapy are discussed. Included, herein, are examples of sesquiterpene [artemisinin (1), parthenolide (2), and thapsigargin (3)], diterpene [(andrographolide (4), ginkgolide B (5), jolkinolide B (6), nagilactone E (7), and triptolide (8)], and triterpene [bruceantin (9), dichapetalin A (10), and limonin (11)] lactones. These representative compounds (1–11) have been selected based on their potent inhibitory activity toward cancer cell growth, the predominant interactions with their molecular targets, or their potential promise for the development of antitumor agents in cancer clinical trials. Thus far, several compounds discussed or their derivatives (1–4, 8, and 9) have been evaluated in phase I or II clinical trials (Table 1). Certain other terpenoid lactones that show potential antitumor activity have not been included in the present perspective, owing to space limitations.
    Table 1. Plant-Derived Terpenoid Lactones with Potential Antitumor Activity
    compoundplant originantitumor potentialmajor targetref.
    artemisinin (1, ART)Artemisia annuaphase I cancer clinical trialAkt(11,14,19,21,24)
    AR
    NF-κB
    parthenolide (2, PTL)Chrysanthemum partheniumphase I cancer clinical trialNF-κB(11,40)
    HIF

    thapsigargin (3, TPG)Thapsia garganicaIC50 = 30 nM (S180 sarcoma cells), with an analogue mipsagargin (3b) tested in phases I and II cancer clinical trialsAMPK(62,67,69,71,75,82,83)
    PKC
    SERCA
    andrographolide (4, AGL)Andrographis paniculataIC50 = 2.4 μM (HL-60 human leukemia cells), tested in phase I cancer clinical trialAkt/mTOR(84,85,87,90,91,93)

    YAP

    Sesquiterpene Lactones

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Sesquiterpene lactones (SQLs) have been well investigated for their potential antitumor activity through several pertinent mechanisms, including inhibition of the SERCA pump and NF-κB activation and modulation of signal transducers and activators of transcription 3 (STAT3).(11) Thus far, several SQLs have been evaluated in cancer clinical trials, including artesunate, dimethylaminoparthenolide, and mipsagargin (G-202).(14) The structure determination and antitumor potential of artemisinin (1), parthenolide (2), thapsigargin (3), and some of their naturally occurring or synthetic analogues have been summarized in 2016 in our previous review,(11) and in this update, more recent progress only of the development of these SQLs as new antitumor agents is discussed in the following paragraphs.

    Artemisinin

    Artemisinin (ART, 1), having the (3R,5aS,6R,8aS,9R,12S,12aR) absolute configuration (Figure 1), is an important naturally occurring endoperoxide-containing sesquiterpene lactone extracted from Artemisia annua L. (Asteraceae).(11) Although superseded by several clinically used semisynthetic derivatives today, ART has been used for the treatment of malaria for several decades, for which the 2015 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was shared by Professor Youyou Tu for her contribution to the field (http://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/2015/press.html). ART (1) has shown also selective antitumor efficacy toward several tumor xenograft models, with multiple molecular targets characterized. These include the interactions between its essential endoperoxide bridge and ferrous iron for generating free radicals to lead to cancer cell death, as discussed in reviews published in 2016 and 2017.(11,15) ART was found recently to suppress hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) cell growth, migration, and invasion by inactivation of Hippo-YAP signal transduction,(16) and it inhibited SKOV3 human ovarian epithelial cancer cell growth via autophagy-mediated cell cycle arrest.(17)
    In the case of a 51-year-old male patient who suffered adrenocortical carcinoma (ACC) with liver and peritoneal metastases and after the failure of several prior antineoplastic therapies, a durable disease response was observed by an up to two-year-treatment with oral dosing by artemisinin tablets (ART 99%) (600 mg dose for 5 days, followed by 5 days without therapy).(18) The patient did not suffer from any symptoms or clinical signs of toxicity. Although only one patient was involved in this clinical investigation, further preclinical and clinical studies for a better understanding of the mechanism and clinical anti-ACC efficacy were recommended for ART.(18)
    Mechanistically, ART has been found to inhibit UMRC-2 and CAKI-2 human clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) cell growth through inhibition of the Akt [protein kinase B (PKB)] signaling pathway.(19) It interacted with P-glycoprotein (P-gp) to reverse P-gp-mediated MDR to support the design of proposed rational ART-based combination cancer chemotherapies.(20) ART prevented Helicobacter pylori-induced gastric carcinogenesis via inhibition of nuclear factor kappa B (NF-κB) signaling.(21) Interestingly, ART was found to enhance significantly the cytolytic activity of natural killer (NK) cells and the antitumor immune response in 4T1 breast cancer cells.(22,23) It selectively induced the ubiquitin-26S proteasome-mediated degradation of androgen receptor (AR) without altering receptor transcript levels in androgen-responsive LNCaP and PC-3 human prostate cancer cells.(24) The ART-induced loss of AR prevented the cell proliferation and ablated total AR transcriptional activity, in which PI3K (phosphoinositide 3-kinase)/Akt-1 signaling played an important role. Thus, the potential of AR-targeted prostate cancer chemotherapy was suggested for ART (Figure 2).(24) In addition, two synthetic derivatives of ART, dihydroartemisinin (DHA, 1a) and artesunate (ARS, 1b), were found to suppress transforming growth factor-β (TGF-β, a recruiter and activator of fibroblasts in many cancers) signaling to inactivate cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs). This resulted in the inhibition of CAF mouse fibroblast L-929 cell growth and metastasis.(25)
    On the basis of ART, [email protected], a cathepsin B-controllable nanoformulation, employing transferrin (Tf)-peptide-modified mesoporous silica (MSN) to codeliver ART and buthionine-sulfoximine (BSO), a glutathione scavenger, was designed and prepared. Using this system, the Tf-peptide targeted MCF-7 human breast cancer cells to supply additional Fe2+, which catalyzes ART, to produce extra reactive oxygen species (ROS) to kill MCF-7 cells efficiently.(26) However, its generally low potency and the generation of MDR have both limited the promise of ART for potential development as an anticancer drug.(19,25,26) To combat these challenges, increasing numbers of ART synthetic derivatives showing improved antitumor activity have been prepared, with some of these having been evaluated in cancer clinical trials, including dihydroartemisinin (DHA, 1a) and artesunate (ARS, 1b).(15,27) Among these derivatives, dimerization and hybridization have proved to be of interest for further oncolytic drug development.(27,28) For example, a nonacetal-type amide-linked deoxoartemisinin dimer, 10-(2′-aminoethyl)deoxoartemisinin dimer (1c), exhibited pronounced activity against MCF-7 human breast cancer cells, with an IC50 value of 8 nM.(29) Several fused ART-piperazine-dithioformates were found to be active against human cancer cells, of which the compound 4-cyanobenzyl-ART-piperazinecarbodithioate (1d) showed the most potent activity, with IC50 values of 2.5 and 14 nM against the SMMC-7721 liver and MCF-7 breast human cancer cell lines, respectively (Figure 1).(30) Thus, both changing the C-10 carbonyl group to a hydroxy group and dimerization of the molecule resulted in the cytotoxicity of 1 being enhanced (Figure 3).
    Currently, the MDR of oncolytic agents has limited the efficient treatment of many types of cancer, so combination chemotherapy with more than one molecular target is a promising approach to overcome this problem, as evidenced by ART and several of its derivatives.(31) Thus, a number of ART-estrogen hybrids have been synthesized, and they all exhibited cytotoxicity against human MCF-7, MDA-MB-231, MDA-MB-361, and T47D breast and C33A cervical cancer cells, with the activity improved around 10-fold when compared with their respective parent compounds. Of these, benzylestrondiol-ART nonacetal hybrid (1e) was the most potent, showing IC50 values of 0.45, 0.86, and 0.15 μM against MCF-7, MDA-MB-231, and C33A cells, respectively (Figure 1), indicating that hybridization of ART may have translational potential for developing innovative anticancer agents.(32)
    In addition, B-cell lymphoma 2 (Bcl-2) proteins are the key regulators of apoptosis and are overexpressed in tumors, and selective blockade of Bcl-2 represents an attractive cancer target. Several series of compounds synthesized from ART were found to display inhibitory activity against Bcl-2, of which some compounds showed high potency, with IC50 values being less than 2.0 nM,(33) indicating that ART could be a potential lead for the design of Bcl-2-targeted anticancer agents.
    In a Phase I, dose-escalation study to assess the safety and efficacy of self-administered artesunate (ARS) vaginal inserts, a total of 28 biopsy-confirmed cervical intraepithelial neoplasia 2/3 (CIN2/3) patients received 1, 2, or 3 five-day treatment cycles (200 mg inserts/time) at study weeks 0, 2, and 4, for 15 weeks. A modified intention-to-treat analysis showed that an overall histologic regression to CIN1 or less was observed in 19 patients, and clearance of HPV genotypes detected at baseline occurred in nine subjects for whom the lesions underwent histologic regression. These findings supported proceeding to Phase II clinical studies for the treatment of CIN2/3 with the topical use of ARS and further indicate the promise for the development of ART-based anticancer agents.(34)

    Parthenolide

    As summarized previously from the period of 2013–2020, (4R,5S,6S,7S)-parthenolide (PTL, 2), an epoxylated germacranolide isolated from Chrysanthemum parthenium L. [syn. Tanacetum parthenium L. (Asteraceae)] (Figure 4), has shown cytotoxicity against various human cancer cells and inhibited selectively cancer stem cell (CSC) growth in leukemia and solid tumors, by interacting with multiple molecular targets.(11,35,36) PTL (2) is known to target acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) progenitor and leukemia stem cells (LSCs) that are essential to the growth and potential relapse of acute and chronic myelogenous leukemia (AML and CML) to induce selective robust apoptosis in primary human AML cells and blast crisis CML cells. Such LSC apoptosis induction is mediated by inhibition of nuclear factor kappa B (NF-κB), proapoptotic activation of p53, and by the generation of increased ROS. Thus, PTL shows promise for the design of LSC-targeted antileukemic agents.(37) Also, it inhibited Panc-1 and BxPC3 human pancreatic cancer cell growth by inducing autophagy-mediated apoptosis, which suggests that PTL could be a potential pancreatic cancer chemotherapeutic agent.(38)
    In addition, PTL was found to inhibit the proliferation of multidrug-resistant cancer cells. The sensitivity of SGC-7901 human gastric cancer cells to DDP (cisplatin) was enhanced by PTL, and significant apoptosis was induced in drug-resistant SGC-7901/DDP human gastric cancer cells treated with PTL. The proliferation, migration, and invasion of SGC-7901/DDP cells were inhibited by PTL through inhibition of the STAT3 signaling pathway.(39) It also inhibited multidrug-resistant MDA-MB-231-BCRP cell growth through the NF-κB and hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF) pathways directly or indirectly. BCRP is a member of the adenosine triphosphate (ATP) binding cassette proteins of efflux transporters responsible for drug disposition and distribution, and expression of BCRP is associated with the tumor response to chemotherapy and resistance. Moreover, PTL has been found to inhibit histone deacetylase (HDAC) activity, which stabilizes HIF-α by decreasing the expression of the von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) tumor suppressor and the tumor protein p53 (p53).(40)
    HIF-1 promotes cancer progression partially by inducing the epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT), a phenotypic change in which epithelial cells are transformed to spindle-like motile cells that express mesenchymal markers, and through which cancer cells undergo migration and invasion leading to cancer progression and metastasis. Both HIF and hypoxia-induced EMT play key roles in tumor metastasis, and hence, they are regarded as promising targets for the development of new and effective anticancer therapies. The 2019 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded jointly to William G. Kaelin, Peter J. Ratcliffe, and Gregg L. Semenza, for their discoveries of how cells sense and adapt to oxygen availability (https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/medicine/2019/summary). PTL was found to inhibit HIF-1α and hypoxia-mediated EMT through blockade of NF-κB activation to mediate its cytotoxicity toward human colorectal cancer (CRC) HT-29, DLD-1, and HCT116 cells.(41) Thus, PTL shows promise also for development as a novel HIF-1α inhibitor to treat cancer.
    Furthermore, PTL activates p53-mediated caspase-dependent apoptosis and inhibits angiogenesis to suppress the proliferation of human A549 nonsmall-cell and H526 small-cell lung cancer cells, and it also inhibited the tumor-promoting effects of nicotine in A549 and H526 cells.(42) It was found recently to target C427 of focal adhesion kinase 1 (FAK1) to inhibit FAK1 activity and its downstream signaling, which leads to impairment of breast cancer cell proliferation, survival, and motility.(43) By targeting ribosome proteins L10 (RPL10) that regulate selectively T-cell factor 4 (TCF4)/lymphoid enhancer factor 1 (LEF1) synthesis without affecting β-catenin translation and blocking TCF4/LEF1 synthesis, PTL inhibited Wnt (Wingless-related integration site)/β-catenin signaling and decreased the TCF4/LEF1 protein levels in HEK293 human embryonic kidney cells. It also significantly reduced the TCF4 levels in human SW480, Caco2, and HT-29 colon cancer cells and inhibited expression of the Wnt target gene NKD1 to suppress proliferation of these colon cancer cells.(44) The Wnt/β-catenin pathway plays an essential role in both embryo development and adult tissue homeostasis, and overactivation of this signaling pathway is related closely to tumor formation and progression. Thus, PTL potentially could be used to treat Wnt-driven tumors.(44)
    However, even though PTL shows some promise for development as a novel CSC-targeted anticancer drug with lowered MDR occurrence, its low potency and poor water solubility are limiting factors in this regard. A preliminary SAR (structure–activity relationship) study showed that saturation of the C-11/C-13 double bond or introduction of an additional epoxy group at the C-1 and C-10 positions of PTL resulted in abolished inhibitory activity against Wnt/β-catenin signaling in HEK293 cells, indicating the importance of these pharmacophores.(44) Following these conclusions, two novel hybrid molecules, namely, parthabine (2a) and parthalan (2b), were synthesized from PTL and two water-soluble anticancer drugs, cytarabine, an antimetabolic agent used for the treatment of AML and acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL), and melphalan, a drug used against various types of cancers, respectively. The aqueous solubility of 2a and 2b was increased when compared with PTL, and both prodrugs showed more potent cytotoxicity than PTL, cytarabine, melphalan, PTL plus cytarabine, or PTL plus melphalan toward human HepG2 liver, LNCaP prostate, and MCF-7 breast cancer cells (Figure 4).(45) In turn, a water-soluble amino derivative of PTL, dimethylaminoparthenolide (DMAPT or LC-1, 2c), was prepared, which showed potent cytotoxicity against AML cells.(46) DMAPT inhibited CWR22Rv1 and PC3 human prostate cancer cell growth through generating ROS and inhibition of NF-κB activity.(47) It was cytotoxic toward AsPC-1, BxPC-3, MiaPaca-2, and Panc-1 human pancreatic cancer cells and decreased the expression of RPL10 and either p65 or IKKγ to inhibit the NF-κB pathway in Panc-1 and MiaPaca-2 cells.(48)
    Radiation therapy (RT) is a critical treatment for advanced nonsmall cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC), but it may result in toxic lesions as characterized by DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs). DMAPT was found to inhibit NF-κB binding activity and DNA DSB repair, which increased the radiation-induced NSCLC cell death,(49,50) and it radioprotected normal tissues and sensitized prostate tumors to radiation-induced damage.(51) Thus, DMAPT could be used as a radioprotector in conjunction with cancer radiotherapy or as a NSCLC radiosensitizer for use clinically.
    A triple drug regimen termed PDT was designed and prepared. This contained PTL to target LSC, 2-deoxyglucose to inhibit dihydronicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH) production from the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP), and temsirolimus to inhibit the nuclear factor erythroid 2-related factor 2 (Nrf2)-mediated oxidative stress responses in AML cells. PDT was more potently toxic than PTL toward both bulk and stem/progenitor populations of primary AML cells, and it showed very limited toxicity toward normal hematopoietic cells. Also, PDT was effective against AML cells that are relatively resistant to PTL, and it mediated antileukemic activity through inducing oxidative stress but without activating the compensatory Nrf2 and PPP responses in primary AML cells.(52) Following this, increased antitumor efficacy was observed for a cocktail liposome therapy (CLT) when nude mice were inoculated with A549 NSCLC cells, and tumors were formed. The tumor-bearing mice were treated (i.v., every 3 days) with a cocktail therapy (CT) of betulinic acid (20.3 mg/kg), ginsenoside Rh2 (20.0 mg/kg), honokiol (20.7 mg/kg), plus parthenolide (20.5 mg/kg), which synergize with each other or this CLT, with the doses of the four natural products being identical with the doses used for the CT, for nine treatment cycles.(53)
    A series of triazole derivatives of melampomagnolide B (14-hydroxy-PTL) has been synthesized, of which 4-nitrophenoxytriazolmethylmelapomagnolide B (2d) showed the most potent activity toward the cancer cells tested, with up to a 10-fold enhancement compared to PTL (Figure 4). Compound 2d induced apoptosis and inhibited proliferation and migration of HCT116 cells, and thus, it was considered as a promising lead compound candidate.(54) Several other synthetic products with melampomagnolide B conjugated with cinnamic acid or its derivatives have been prepared, of which most compounds showed more potent cytotoxicity than the parent natural product toward MDA-MB-231 human triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) cells.(55) Also, several parthenolide-5-fluorouracil (5-FU) (PTL-5-FU) conjugates were synthesized and evaluated against human Bel-7402 HCC cells and the 5-FU-resistant HCC cell line, Bel-7402/5-FU. Some compounds showed enhanced cytotoxicity against both Bel-7402 and Bel-7402/5-FU cells when compared with PTL or 5-FU, including compound 2e, indicating promise for the development of PTL-based anti-HCC drugs.(56)
    Previously, a furano-analogue of PTL, (+)-goyazensolide (2f), containing a furan ring between the C-3 and C-10 positions, a carbonyl group at the C-1 position, and an ester group at the C-8 position, was isolated and identified as a cytotoxic principle compound from the leaves of Piptocoma rufescens Cass. (Asteraceae).(57) The complete structure of this compound with a (6R,7R,8S,10R) absolute configuration was confirmed by analysis of its single-crystal X-ray diffraction and NMR and ECD spectroscopic data, inclusive of values of −0.04(13) defined from the Flack parameter and −0.03(4) as determined from the Hooft y parameter, in our recent investigations on this compound.(58) (+)-Goyazensolide (2f) was highly cytotoxic toward HT-29 human colon cancer cells and MOLM-13 and EOL-1 human leukemia cells.(57,58) In an vivo study, it exhibited antitumor efficacy when immunodeficient NCr nu/nu mice implanted with hollow fibers containing HT-29 cells were treated intraperitoneally (i.p.) daily with (+)-goyazensolide (2f) at doses of 12.5 mg/kg for 4 days.(59) Similar to PTL, (+)-goyazensolide (2f) inhibited colon tumor growth by targeting selectively NF-κB,(59) and it prohibited the proliferation of Sch10545 and Ben-Men cells by reducing the levels of cyclins A and E, phospho-Akt, and NF-κB. Thus, it may have potential for treating neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2)-associated schwannomas and meningiomas.(60) Also, (+)-goyazensolide (2f) showed superior in vitro antileukemic potency when compared with PTL, and it was synergistic with midostaurin against both MOLM-13 and EOL-1 cells. Thus, (+)-goyazensolide could be a promising NF-κB-targeted antileukemic lead.(58)
    Recently, PTL was characterized as a potential pyruvate kinase M2 (PKM2) activator, and several PTL-related dimers were synthesized and tested against PKM2, of which compound 2g was found to show the greatest PKM2-activator activity, showing an IC50 value of 15 nM (Figure 5). Also, this dimer (2g) was found to be the most potently cytotoxic, and it inhibited proliferation and metastasis of glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) cells. A preliminary SAR study showed that the length of the linker between the two melampomagnolide B units present is important, with derivatives containing longer linkers exhibiting less potent cytotoxicity against U118 GBM cells. To improve on water solubility, a prodrug, 2h, was synthesized from 2g, which was found to show an ability to penetrate the blood–brain barrier (BBB) and potent antitumor efficacy. Thus, GBM tumor growth was inhibited when 5–6-week-old Bar b/c nude mice were inoculated by U118 GBM cells (1 day) and treated (i.p.) with 2h (50 mg/kg, twice a week) for 3 weeks.(61) On the basis of these modifications of 2, introducing a N-containing substituent at C-13 or dimerization of the molecule appears to enhance the cytotoxicity of 2 (Figure 6).
    PKM2 acts as a key metabolic regulator to support cancer cells to maintain a balance of energy and biomolecule precursor requirements, and activation of PKM2 has emerged as a useful target for the discovery of new anticancer agents. Compound 2g functions as a potent PKM2 activator, with its prodrug 2h showing the potential to penetrate the BBB, and thus, the PTL dimer 2h was proposed as an anti-GBM lead compound.(61) This indicates that dimerization of PTL could be a reasonable strategy for the design and discovery of novel PTL-based anti-GBM agents.

    Thapsigargin

    (1R,2S,3S,6S,7R,8S,10S,11S)-Thapsigargin (TPG, 3), a SQL isolated originally from the roots of Thapsia garganica L. (Apiaceae), was identified as a skin-irritant principle of this plant (Figure 7).(11,62) It has been characterized as a potent sarco/endoplasmic reticulum (ER) calcium ATPase (SERCA) inhibitor and also exhibits cytotoxicity toward human cancer cell lines.(62,63) Phytochemical information, synthesis methodology, and SAR observations for the inhibitory activities against the SERCA pump and human cancer cell growth of TPG and its derivatives have been summarized from 2015 to 2018,(11,62−64) and discussed below is an update of these previous reviews on this compound.
    TPG was identified by Christensen and colleagues in 1980.(65) It was demonstrated later as a weak tumor-promoting agent when 7–8-week-old female CD-I mice were treated topically with 5 μg of TPG twice a week for 30 weeks, and papillomas and carcinomas were counted every 2 weeks for 52 weeks. Also, a low risk for conversion of these papillomas to malignancies was indicated by the rapid regression of these TPG-promoted papillomas after a 40-week treatment.(66) Further biological studies showed that TPG is potently cytotoxic toward murine EL4 lymphoma (IC50 = 0.1 μM) and S180 sarcoma (IC50 = 0.03 μM) cells, but it showed a lesser activity against MCF-7 human breast cancer cells (IC50 = 2.3 μM) (Figure 7).(67) TPG resulted in a loss of clonogenic survival of TSU-Pr1 human prostate cancer cells, while it inhibited skeletal muscle Ca2+-ATPase (SERCA), with a low IC50 value of 3.9 nM.(68)
    As a potent SERCA inhibitor, TPG discharges intracellular Ca2+ stores in rat hepatocytes by specific inhibition of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) Ca2+-ATPase, and it provides a powerful laboratory tool to test the biochemical functions of SERCA.(69) For example, an overall correlation was observed between the inhibition of SERCA and the induction of LNCaP and PC3 human prostate cancer cell death by TPG. Both ER Ca2+ drainage and sustained unfolded protein response (UPR) were found important for TPG to induce LNCaP and PC3 cell apoptosis at a low concentration.(70) Influx of Ca2+ caused by the treatment of human DLD-1 colorectal and SK-OV-3 ovarian cancer cells with TPG enhanced oncolytic adenovirus enadenotucirev (EnAd) replication and cell killing through PKCα (protein kinase C-α) activation. This indicates a signaling pathway between PKC and adenovirus early region 1A (E1A), as well as the possibility of Ca2+ flux-involved potentiation of oncolytic virotherapies.(71) In addition, the level of S100A4 protein in MDA-MB-231 human TNBC cells was found to be decreased significantly by the treatment of cells with TPG, but the cell viability was not inhibited, suggesting that S100A4 gene transcription may be regulated by Ca2+ signaling pathways.(72) S100A4, known as metastasin-1, is a calcium-binding protein known to regulate cancer development, while TPG inhibits effectively SERCA to increase Ca2+ levels in the cytoplasm of cells. Thus, the mechanism of SERCA inhibition by TPG could be supportive of the design of novel anticancer agents targeting tumor metastasis.(72)
    In addition, TPG induced endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress that may invoke apoptosis to prohibit the proliferation of PC3 human prostate cancer cells. This could be mediated through the Akt-mTOR and F-actin/cofilin-1/paxillin pathways, as shown by its inhibition of Akt activity and expression of m-TOR, F-actin, and paxillin and induction of caspase-3/9 activities and cofilin-1 expression in PC3 cells.(73) Induction of ER stress can lead to the formation of autophagic vehicles, which triggers subsequently autophagic or apoptotic cell death. Thus, TPG was found to inhibit MCF-7 human breast cancer cell growth through induction of sequential expression of autophagy and apoptosis-related proteins in cells.(74) Also, TPG-induced ER stress increased the expression of the cytosine-cytosine-adenosine-adenosine-thymidine (CCAAT)-enhancer-binding protein (C/EBP) homologous protein (CHOP) and the subsequent upregulation of the death receptor 5 (DR5) to promote human esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) cell apoptosis. In turn, it inhibited selectively EC109 and TE12 ESCC cell growth, migration, adhesion, and invasion through induction of CHOP in ESCC cells to induce cell apoptosis. TPG also sensitized EC109 and TE12 esophageal cancer cells to tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-related apoptosis-inducing ligand (TRAIL)-induced apoptosis via AMPK activation, indicating that activation of ER stress by TPG may support TRAIL-based cancer chemotherapy.(75)
    In mammalian cells, Sec62, a membrane protein of the ER, interacts with the ribosomal tunnel exit to support cotranslational protein entry to regulate ER calcium homeostasis, and the siRNA-mediated depletion of Sec62 was found to sensitize the cancer cells to TPG treatment. Addition of the calmodulin (a multifunctional intermediate calcium-binding messenger protein) antagonist trifluoperazine, an antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia, was found to mimic the Sec62 depletion phenotype to sensitize cancer cells to TPG, indicating a potential therapeutic option of treating Sec62-overproducing tumors with a combination therapy of TPG plus trifluoperazine. Such a possible approach was substantiated by an in vivo investigation, where tumor growth was inhibited when eight-week-old athymic nude mice were inoculated by FaDu human hypopharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma cells, and the tumor-bearing mice were treated (i.p., three times a week) with TPG (1.6 mg/kg) or TPG (1.6 mg/kg) plus trifluoperazine (0.5 mg/kg) for 5 weeks, after solid tumors occurred.(76)
    Mechanistically, TPG induces HCT116 human colon cancer cell apoptosis by activating Bax, a crucial mediator of the mitochondrial pathway, through a caspase-8-dependent pathway. This leads to the release of Smac and Omi into the cytosol to amplify the caspase-8 signal for the activation of caspase-3 and apoptosis.(77) In addition, Bax downregulates interleukin-8 (IL-8) expression, and both IL-8 and Hsp60 promote apoptosis resistance in cancer. As a noncompetitive SERCA inhibitor, TPG was found to induce the robust expression of IL-8, since a nanomolar combination of TPG with the histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitor apicidin (Api) reduced IL-8 expression and induced apoptosis in human HCT116 colon and LNCaP prostate cancer cells. Interestingly, Bax reconstitution induced cancer cell death in response to the combination treatment of Api and TPG, and IL-8 release was reduced drastically upon Hsp60 knockdown, which inhibits the TGF-β expression that was decreased in LNCaP cells treated with TPG or TPG plus Api. Thus, Hsp60 could regulate IL-8 expression and its upstream regulator TGF-β in cancer cells, and a combination of TPG and Api may abrogate the Hsp60-IL-8-TGF-β axis to overcome apoptotic resistance, which could potentiate the therapeutic outcome in colorectal and prostate malignancies.(78)
    To develop TPG as an effective anticancer agent, a derivative, namely, L12ADT (3a), showing potent activity toward LNCaP cells (IC50 14 nM) comparable to TPG (IC50 10 nM), was produced by successfully coupling a 12-aminododecanoyl side-chain analogue of TPG to leucine. L12ADT was hydrolyzed efficiently by prostate-specific antigen (PSA), and it was selectively toxic to PSA-producing prostate cancer cells. This indicates the potential for the development of PSA-activated TPG prodrugs for the treatment of metastatic prostate cancer(79,80) and introducing a large substituent at the C-8 position seems to enhance the antitumor potential of 3 (Figure 8). Thus, a promising TPG prodrug, mipsagargin (3b, also named G-202), was produced by solid-phase synthesis protocols (Figure 7), which is based on the hypothesis that the extracellular prostate-specific membrane antigen (PSMA) may be used to cleave the masking peptide to deliver mipsagargin into tumors specifically.(81)
    The maximum tolerated dose (MTD), the dose-limiting toxicities (DLTs), the pharmacokinetics, and the recommended phase II dose of mipsagargin (3b) have been determined in a phase I clinical trial study. Altogether, 44 patients (28 patients in the dose escalation phase and 16 patients in an expansion cohort), with different types of locally advanced or metastatic solid tumors, were treated (i.v.) continuously with mipsagargin on days 1, 2, and 3 of 28-day cycles at doses ranging from 1.2 to 88 mg/m2 until evidence was shown of disease progression or unacceptable toxicity. Mipsagargin was generally well tolerated and demonstrated a favorable pharmacokinetic profile in the patients, and a prolonged disease stabilization was observed in the advanced HCC patients. The recommended phase II dose (RP2D) of 40 mg/m2 on day 1 and that of 66.8 mg/m2 on days 2 and 3 with prophylactic premedications and hydration on each day of infusion to help ameliorate the infusion-related reaction (IRR) were established.(82)
    A phase II multicenter and single-arm study, with mipsagargin used as a second-line therapy following sorafenib, has been completed. Altogether, 19 patients with progressive advanced HCC after treatment with sorafenib or intolerant of sorafenib were treated (i.v.) with mipsagargin at a dose of 40 mg/m2 on days 1–3 of each 28-day cycle. Mipsagargin was found to be relatively well tolerated and promoted prolonged disease stabilization in patients. Importantly, a significant decrease in Ktrans upon the treatment was observed, suggesting that mipsagargin could reduce blood flow in hepatic lesions, and thus, it may have the necessary activity to be evaluated in a larger clinical study.(83)
    From being a skin-irritant plant component and a tumor promoter to a tumor inhibitor and then an anticancer prodrug, TPG functions as a potent SERCA inhibitor to prevent the reuptake of calcium from the cytosol to the ER to induce cancer cell apoptosis. The detailed continued investigations of this compound and its derivatives provide a good example of the mechanism-guided development a tumor-targeted agent of natural origin.

    Diterpene Lactones

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Diterpenes are one of the largest groups of NPs and are composed of two monoterpene units derived from four isoprene subunits (C20), of which an increasing number found are diterpene lactones, with either a five-membered γ-lactone or six-membered δ-lactone unit being present. Several compounds of this type of NPs have been investigated for their potent antitumor activity, as exemplified by andrographolide (4), ginkgolide (5), jolkinolide (6), nagilactone (7), and triptolide (8), which will be discussed in turn below.

    Andrographolide

    Andrographolide (4, AGL) is a bitter-tasting labdane-type diterpene lactone derived from a medicinal plant, Andrographis paniculata (Burm.f.) Nees (Acanthaceae), and it has shown moderate but selective cytotoxicity against human cancer cells.(84) The (3R,4R,5S,9R,10S,14S) absolute configuration was determined recently by the refinement of the Flack parameter to 0.21(19) from its single-crystal X-ray diffraction data (Figure 9).(85) Since the potential antitumor activity of AGL and its derivatives has been discussed in two recent review articles in 2018,(86,87) the following paragraphs provide an update to these previous reviews.
    AGL showed cytotoxicity toward U87 MG human glioma cells, and it inhibited U87 MG cell migration, indicating a possibility of use against glioblastoma multiforme (GBM, the most common and aggressive primary brain tumor in adults).(88) It induced apoptosis in HepG2CR cisplatin-resistant human hepatoma cells through the PKA/PP 2A/IKK pathway, demonstrating that AGL may reverse the resistance observed in cisplatin-resistant HepG2CR cells.(89)
    Recently, a combination of AGL with anti-PD-1 (programmed cell death protein 1) antibody was found to show more potent antitumor activity than either individual agent alone, when 6–8 week-old female BALB/c mice were inoculated by CT26 mouse colon carcinoma cells (3 days) and treated (i.p.) with AGL (5 mg/kg, every day) with or without anti-PD-1 (i.p., 5 mg/kg, every 3 days) for 15 days. This AGL and anti-PD-1 combined therapy increased the infiltration and function of CD4+ and CD8+ T cells and tumor suppression cytokine interferon gamma (IFN-γ), perforin, granzyme, and Fas ligand (FasL) expression in tumor tissues. Thus, a combination of a PD-1 blockade with AGL might be a promising strategy for cancer immunotherapy.(90)
    AGL mediates its antitumor potential through several signaling pathways. For example, it protected SH-SY5Y human neuroblastoma cells from bupivacaine-induced cytotoxicity via inhibition of apoptosis, increasing the antioxidative status, and activation of the Akt–mTOR signaling pathway.(91) AGL treatment inhibited cyclooxygenase-2 (COX2, overexpressed in colon cancer to inhibit apoptotic activity, to stimulate adhesion and invasion, and to induce angiogenesis) activity and prostaglandin E2(PGE2) release in CT26 mouse colon cancer cells, and thus, it may contribute to reduction of the immune suppressive microenvironment in tumors.(90) The docking profiles between AGL or meloxicam, a COX2 blocker, and COX2 showed that AGL has a stronger affinity and more stable bonds than meloxicam when binding to COX2.(92) AGL augmented cytotoxicity in SW620 human colon cancer cells through evoking cell apoptosis via suppression of the Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4)/NF-κB/MMP (matrix metalloproteinase)-9 signaling pathway.(93) Also, AGL exhibited antiproliferative effects against HT-29 human colon cancer cells by augmentation of intracellular ROS levels and disruption of mitochondrial transmembrane potential (MTP).(94) It inhibited PC-3 human prostate cancer cell growth by inducing cell apoptosis and decreasing the vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) level in cells.(95)
    Thus, far, andrographolide (4) has been tested in a phase I open-label, randomized, controlled clinical trial. This involved the study of andrographolide with or without capecitabine to treat colorectal cancer (AGCRC-013) (NCT01993472), with 308 participants with unresectable, advanced, recurrent, or metastatic colorectal cancer included. However, this trial study eventually had to be terminated, owing to the low accrual rate (https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01993472).
    Since nanotechnology has offered an opportunity to improve cancer treatments by site-specific and target-directed drug delivery, several new delivery systems have been developed for AGL. Of these, a cell-penetrating peptide (CPP)-assisted liposomal codelivery system (Lipo-CPP) was prepared for AGL plus doxorubicin (DOX), which effectively increased the resultant intratumor infiltration, cellular uptake, and intranuclear accumulation. This Lipo-CPP system exhibited more potent cytotoxicity and inhibitory effects on cell migration and invasion against 4T1 murine breast cancer cells than the free combination of AGL and DOX.(96) Solid lipid nanoparticles to deliver AGL into the brain were prepared using Compritol 888 ATO as a solid lipid and Brij 78 as a surfactant, and these nanoparticles improved the permeability of AGL to cross the blood-brain barrier (BBB) when compared with free AGL.(97) In addition, AGL-loaded regenerated silk fibroin (RSF) as a drug-carrier to encapsulate AGL was prepared successfully, of which the average volume size was about 300 nm, which could be beneficial for lymphatic chemotherapy. These AGL-loaded RSF nanoparticles were shown to adhere to human HeLa cervical and MDA-MB-231 breast cancer cells readily, and they inhibited cell growth more potently than free AGL at concentrations of 50 and 100 μM.(98) More recently, an optimized self-microemulsifying drug delivery system (SMEDDS) was prepared for AGL. It increased significantly the overall solubility and cytotoxicity against MCF-7 human breast cancer cells of AGL and is supportive of the oral drug delivery potential of this compound.(99)
    The relatively weak cytotoxic potency observed against cancer cells is another challenge for the development of AGL as a possible new anticancer agent (Figure 9). Thus, various AGL derivatives were produced by transforming its α-alkylidene-γ-butyrolactone moiety into a C-12-substituted-14-deoxylactone unit. This was completed in each case through a Michael addition reaction, with aminoalkyl, thiophenyl, and substituted aminoaryl groups introduced at the C-12 position of AGL. The cytotoxicity of these synthetic derivatives was evaluated against the NCI60 cell line panel, and those analogues containing a thiophenyl or an aminoaryl group substituted with sulfonamide were found to exhibit the most potent activity toward the majority of the cancer cell lines used. Of these derivatives, 12(α/β)-phenylthio-14-deoxyandrographolide (4a) and 12(α/β)-(N-acetylsulfamoyl)phenylamino)-14-deoxyandrographolide (4b) showed greater activity against HCT116 human colon cancer cells than AGL, with an IC50 value of 0.85 and 1.7 μM, respectively.(100) Also, the 12(α/β)-N-sulfamoylphenylamino-14-deoxyandrographolides 4c and 4d were synthesized, and both compounds showed activity against CCRF-CEM human leukemia cells, with IC50 values of 0.73 and 0.0073 μM, respectively (Figure 9).(101) Two structurally similar naturally occurring labdane diterpenoids, chlorolissoclimide (4e) and dichlorolissoclimide (4f), were found to be powerful cytotoxins toward P-388 murine leukemia cells, with IC50 values of 0.004 and 0.002 μM, respectively.(102) On the basis of the SAR observations as discussed above, the cytotoxicity of 4 could be enhanced by introducing a thiophenyl group at the C-12 position, along with removal of the C-14 hydroxy group followed by introducing a double bond at the C-13/C-14 positions and acetylation of hydroxy group at the C-3 and C-19 positions (Figure 10).
    In addition, a fluorescent AGL derivative, with a nitrobenzoxadiazole (NBD) fluorophore connected at its C-19 hydroxy group, namely, ANDRO-NBD (4g) (Figure 9), was synthesized. This ANDRO-NBD fluorescent conjugate showed more potent activity than AGL toward human cancer cells, and it was used to analyze the uptake kinetics and cellular distribution and to identify the molecular targets of AGL. This fluorescent conjugate should provide a promising tool for the further investigation of the mechanisms of action of AGL and supports the development of this diterpene lactone and its derivatives as antitumor leads.(103)

    Ginkgolide B

    Ginkgo biloba L. (Ginkgoaceae), known as ginkgo, is regarded as a living fossil plant that has existed for more than 250 million years, and the leaf extract acts as a free-radical scavenger of nearly all ROS types and is well tolerated and apparently safe when ingested by humans. Thus, ginkgo is used widely to improve mental alertness and memory and also for enhanced vasodilation for improved blood flow.(104) Recently, ginkgo has become of interest for the treatment and prevention of retinal diseases associated with neurodegeneration, in which the retinal ganglion cells have poor antioxidant capacities and insufficient nucleic acid repair mechanisms.(104) In addition, ginkgo leaves possess antitumor properties, which results from their antioxidant, antiangiogenic, and gene-regulatory activities.(105) For example, a ginkgo leaf extract exhibited cytotoxicity against HepG2 and Hep3B HCC cells,(106) and it suppressed the proliferation of OVCA429 human ovarian cancer cells.(107) Ginkgolides B (GKL B, 5), A (GKL A, 5a), and C (GKL C, 5b), the caged diterpene trilactones comprising six five-membered rings, were isolated as the major bitter principles from the leaves of ginkgo,(108) and their structures were established by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis (Figure 11).(109,110)
    The (1R,2S,3R,4R,5R,6R,8S,9S,10R,12R,14S) absolute configuration of GKL B (5) was determined by analysis of its NMR spectroscopic data and comparison with those of GKL A (5a), for which the (2S,3R,4R,5S,6R,8S,9S,10R,12R,14S) absolute configuration was established from the Flack parameter of −0.02(12) measured by the single-crystal X-ray diffraction with Cu Kα radiation at 296 K for ginkgolide A monohydrate. Following these studies, the (1R,2S,3R,4R,5R,6S,7R,8S,9S,10R,12R,14S) absolute configuration was determined for ginkgolide C (5b) sesquihydrate.(108,111)
    The early biological investigations on GKLs focused on their activity toward platelet-activating factor (PAF or PAF-acether), a naturally occurring etherphospholipid generated by specific activation of rabbit basophils, human and rabbit polymorphonuclears, and human macrophages and eosinophils to potentially mediate anaphylaxis and shock. In 1985, Braquet and colleagues identified GKLs A–C as specific PAF inhibitors, which inhibited both the binding of [3H] PAF-acether to its receptor, with IC50 values (μM) of 0.94 (GKL A), 0.25 (GKL B), and 17 (GKL C), and PAF-dependent platelet aggregation. Of these compounds, GKL B (5) was found to be the most potently active, indicating the importance of the hydroxy groups occurring at the C-6 and C-10 positions.(112) These conclusions were confirmed by investigations of the binding of GKLs and their synthetic derivatives to a cloned PAF receptor (PAFR), which showed that several GKL derivatives containing aromatic photoactivatable substituents at the C-10 position were active PAFR antagonists.(113) Following these observations, more potent PAFR inhibitors, namely, 10-O-(((anthracen-2-yloxy)methyl)-1H-1,2,3-triazole) ginkgolide B (5c), 10-O-(((anthracen-2-yloxy)methyl)-1H-1,2,3-triazole) ginkgolide A (5d), and 10-O-(((anthracen-2-yloxy)methyl)-1H-1,2,3-triazole) ginkgolide C (5e), were synthesized from GKLs B (5), A (5a), and C (5b), respectively, through an azide–alkyne Huisgen cycloaddition reaction. These ginkgolide derivatives showed considerably enhanced PAFR inhibitory activity when compared to their parent compounds (Figure 11), and they did not exhibit any toxicity toward cardiomyocytes and platelets. Of these, the derivative 5c inhibited PAF-induced platelet aggregation at the nanomolar level (IC50 = 5.7 nM).(114) These indicate that introducing a hydroxy group at the C-7 position decreases the PAF inhibitory activity of 5, but substituting a triazole-containing substituent at the C-10 position may increase this effect (Figure 12).
    The role of PAF/PAFR in tumors has been well-documented recently. The tumor microenvironment (TME) is essential for the development of tumors, where PAF-like phospholipids are generated because of the increased apoptotic cells under hypoxia. The overexpressed PAFR may thus induce a regulatory/tolerogenic phenotype to protect cancer cells from death induced by chemotherapy, and hence a combination of PAFR antagonists with other chemotherapeutic agents may benefit cancer treatment.(115) Hence, the upregulation of PAFR was observed in SKOV-3 and CAOV-3 human ovarian cancer cells treated with cisplatin (CDDP), and inhibition of PAFR sensitized the ovarian cancer cells to CDDP.(116) In a recent study, mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) were found to induce the TME to secrete high concentrations of PAF, of which the receptor PAFR was overexpressed in ovarian cancer cells (OCC). Therefore, the tumor-promoting effect of MSCs in OCCs via their interaction in the TME seems, at least in part, to be mediated by the PAF/PAFR pathway, indicating that inhibition of PAFR can suppress ovarian tumor growth.(117)
    As a potent PAF inhibitor, GKL B exhibits multiple bioactivities, including potential anti-Alzheimer’s (i.e., protective effects on neuronal degeneration), anti-inflammatory, antitumor, and antiviral activities, as summarized in 2007 in a review article.(118) Even though GKL B showed no discernible cytotoxicity against OVCA429 human ovarian cancer cells (IC50 > 50 μM),(107) it was found to decrease the level of the zinc finger E-box-binding homeobox 1 (ZEB1) in T24 human bladder cancer cells (IC50 = ∼0.5 μM) to suppress T24 cell invasion via upregulating miR-223-3p.(119) ZEB1 is a protein encoded by the ZEB1 gene and a key promoter of EMT initiation for maintaining the adapted mesenchymal phenotype, which triggers EMT to allow cancer cells to adapt to a phenotype favoring invasiveness and metastases, and thus GKL B may possess some therapeutic potential to reduce bladder cancer metastases.(119)
    Although GKL B did not show any evident growth inhibitory activity against BxPC-3, Capan-1, MiaPaCa-2, and Panc-1 human pancreatic cancer cells, it enhanced the sensitivity, proliferation inhibition, and apoptosis induction of gemcitabine in these cells. This indicates that GKL B might have some therapeutic potential to combat MDR observed in the treatment of pancreatic cancer with gemcitabine.(120) In addition, in HEI-OC1 (the house ear institute-organ of Corti 1) mouse auditory cells, GKL B decreased superoxide generation through down-regulation of p53 and the downstream targets, NOX4 and p66shc regulated by miR214, to inhibit cisplatin-induced cytotoxicity in these cochlear cells,(121) suggesting that GKL B may decrease the side effects on auditory perception of cisplatin in the treatment of cancer.
    In vivo studies have shown that the antiovarian tumor efficacy of CDDP was enhanced markedly by GKL B when four- to six-week-old female athymic nu/nu mice injected by human ovarian cancer SKOV-3-luc cells, with the region of interest of tumor tissues being reached around 1 × 109, and then the mice were treated (i.p.) with GKL B (10 mg per mouse, daily), CDDP (5 mg/kg, once a week), or GKL B (10 mg per mouse, daily) plus CDDP (5 mg/kg, once a week) for 3 weeks.(116) Also, the antipancreatic tumor activity of gemcitabine was potentiated by GKL B when six-week-old nude mice were inoculated by Capan-1 human pancreatic cancer cells (2 weeks) and treated (i.p. every 3 days) with gemcitabine (100 mg/kg), GKL B (40 mg/kg), or gemcitabine (100 mg/kg) plus GKL B (40 mg/kg) for 4 weeks.(120)
    In addition, diethylnitrosamine (DEN)-induced HCC was inhibited by GKL B nanocapsules when adult male Swiss Albino rats were injected intraperitoneally by three doses of DEN (200 mg/kg, in olive oil), with 15-day intervals between doses, and treated (orally by gavage, once a week) with PEG-containing GKL B nanocapsules (5 mg/kg), or GKL B nanocapsules without PEG (5 mg/kg) for 16 weeks.(122) Colitis-associated tumorigenesis and angiogenesis were inhibited significantly when eight-week-old female C57/BL6 mice were injected (i.p.) with azoxymethane (AOM) on day 1, followed by three cycles of 2% dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) in the drinking water for 7 days and treated (i.p., daily) with GKL B (10 mg/kg) for 2 weeks.(123) These results indicate that GKL B may suppress tumorigenesis.
    The tumor-promoting effect of PAF could be mediated by acting against both tumor and host cells, for which activation of PAFR at the cellular level may increase cell resistance to injury induced by chemotherapeutic drugs, while that at the tissue level could promote the clearance of dying cells, apoptotic bodies, or cell debris to trigger a loop for tumor cell repopulation.(115) Several 10-triazole synthetic derivatives of GKL B, including 5c, 5d, and 5e (Figure 11) exhibited more potent PAFR inhibitory activity than GKL B itself, and thus, these compounds could be investigated for their in vivo antitumor potential and mechanism of action. Following this, GKL B and its derivatives 5c–5e might be evaluated in cancer clinical trials as an adjuvant therapy, with the development of ginkgolide drug conjugates being supportive of established cancer treatments.

    Jolkinolide B

    Jolkinolide B (JKL B, 6, Figure 13) was isolated originally from the fresh roots of Euphorbia jolkini Boiss. (Euphorbiaceae) in the early 1970s,(124) and it was characterized later as a major bioactive component of the dried roots of Euphorbia fischeriana Steud (Euphorbiaceae).(125) The structure of JKL B was confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction data,(126) with the (5R,8S,9R,10R,11R,12R,14R) absolute configuration determined by comparison of its spectroscopic data with those of a closely related analogue, fischeriabietane E (6a), for which the configuration was assigned by analysis of the experimental and calculated ECD spectra.(125)
    An early study showed JKL B to be cytotoxic against HeLa human cervical cancer cells (IC50 7.0 μM),(126) and, as summarized recently in 2018, it exhibited inhibitory effects on cell growth against a panel of human cancer cells, with IC50 values being in the range 10–250 μM.(127) For example, it suppressed the proliferation of human A549 and HepG2 liver cancer cells and induced apoptosis in these cells and in HUVECs (human umbilical vein endothelial cells).(128,129) It inhibited the adhesion of MDA-MB-231 human breast cancer cells to fibronectin and thus showed a potential antimetastatic effect on breast cancer.(130) In an in vivo study, JKL B was found to suppress melanoma growth through induction of apoptosis in B16F10 mouse melanoma cells when C57BL/6 mice were inoculated by B16F10 cells (1 week) and treated daily (i.g.) with JKL B at doses of 10, 20, and 40 mg/kg for a week, with the tumor growth inhibition rates being 17.3%, 34.6% and 54.4%, respectively.(131)
    JKL B (6) mediates its potential antitumor activity by multiple mechanisms demonstrated so far. It reduces the expression of the VEGF protein in A549 cell xenograft lung tumors by inhibiting the Akt/STAT3/mTOR signaling,(128) while it attenuated the attachment of MDA-MB-231 human breast cancer cells to fibronectin by modulation of the integrin/focal adhesion kinase (FAK) and ERK (extracellular signal-regulated kinases) pathways.(130) It reduces cell viability and induced apoptosis in HL-60 and THP-1 human leukemic cells, at least in part, through the downregulation of Janus kinases2 (JAK2)/STAT3,(132) and it was found to induce MCF-7 breast cancer cell apoptosis by inhibition of the PI3K/Akt/mTOR signaling pathway.(133)
    In addition, JKL B induced apoptosis in HT-29 and SW620 human colon cancer cells through a ROS-ER stress-Ca2+-mitochondrial dependent pathway. The generation of invoked ROS and ER stress by JKL B triggered Ca2+ release from the ER and mitochondrial Ca2+ uptake that led to mitochondrial depolarization, and thus JKL B was proposed as a potential anticolon tumor agent.(134) Intriguingly, JKL B inhibited A549 and H1299 NSCLC cell viability through reduction of the glucose consumption, lactate production, and hexokinase 2 (HK2) expression in cells by targeting the Akt/mTOR pathway.(135) Similarly, it mediated its antimelanoma activity through downregulation of the mRNA expression of genes of glucose transporters (GLUTs 1, 3, and 4) and glycolysis-related kinase [HK2 and LDHA (lactate dehydrogenase A)] in B16F10 mouse melanoma cells.(131)
    It has been necessary to identify the pharmacophores of JKL B through SAR investigations with the objective of improving its antitumor potential. Comparison of the cytotoxicity of JKL B and several naturally occurring analogues showed that 17-hydroxyjolkinolide B (6b) was less potently active than JKL B itself, indicating that introducing a hydroxy group at the C-17 position diminishes the resultant potency.(136) Quite potent inhibitory activity against Ramos B human Burkitt’s lymphoma cells (IC50 0.059 μM) was observed for 17-acetoxyjolkinolide B (6c),(137) suggesting that 17-acetylation may improve the cytotoxicity of 6. De-epoxylation at the C-11 and C-12 positions resulted in the cytotoxic potency being decreased, as shown for fischeriabietane E (6a), which did not display any activity toward human Bel-7402 lung, HT-29 colon, and Panc-28 pancreatic cancer cells, and jolkinolide A (6d) that was much less active than 6.(125,136) Further hydroxylation at C-17 of 6d increased its activity, as indicated by caudicifolin (6e) (Figure 13),(125,136) and introducing a conjugated system over C-8 and C-13–C-15 and a C-17 hydroxy group enhanced the cytotoxicity of JKL B against ANA-1 murine macrophages and Jurkat human T lymphoma cells.(138) Thus, the natural product mangiolide (6f) was more active than 6, showing cytotoxicity against human MCF-7 breast cancer and UACC62 melanoma cells, with IC50 values of 0.13 and 0.08 μM, respectively.(139) These SAR conclusions suggest that the cancer cell cytotoxicity of JKL B may be improved by modifications at the C-8, C-11–C-14, and C-17 positions, and a conjugated C-14 carbonyl group seems important for the mediation of this type of activity. Removal of the epoxy group at the C-11 and C-12 positions decreases the cytotoxic potency of 6, but introducing a C-14 carbonyl group conjugated with double bonds at C-7(8) and C13(15) positions potentiates the cytotoxicity of 6 (Figure 14).
    It is worthy noting that while 17-hydroxyjolkinolide B (6b) showed a only weak tumor cell cytotoxicity,(136) it inhibited strongly IL-6-induced STAT3 activation by directing the JAK family kinases and induced apoptosis in HepG2 hepatoma cells,(140) while 17-acetoxyjolkinolide B (6c) was found to inhibit NF-κB signaling by directly interacting with IKK-β.(141) Thus, both 6b and 6c show some promise as antitumor agents by targeting the JAK/STAT3 and NF-κB pathways.
    Cancer cells require large amounts of glucose transported by glucose transporters (GLUTs) to meet their rapid proliferation rate, and GLUTs have attracted wide interest for the potential treatment or diagnosis of cancer. Many plant-derived glucose transport inhibitors have been found to show potential antitumor activity, and some of these may have use in addressing the management of toxicity and MDR observed with current anticancer drugs.(142) As discussed above, JKL B inhibited glycolysis in human NSCLC and mouse melanoma cells and showed antitumor activity,(131,135) and several of its analogues showed more potent tumor cell cytotoxicity than JKL B. Thus, the development of JKL B as a new anticancer agent by targeting GLUTs to lower side effects could be a promising future strategy, and this is supported by its high nontoxic i.p. dose of 40 mg/kg that was able to be used in an animal model.(131)

    Nagilactone E

    Nagilactone E (NGL E, 7, Figure 15) is a labdane-type C19-norditerpene dilactone isolated and identified from the leaves and seeds of Podocarpus nagi Zoll. et Moritzi and the roots and bark of Podocarpus macrophyllus D. Don (Podocarpaceae).(143,144) The structure of NGL E was supported from single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of its close natural analogues makilactone I (7a) and 3-deoxy-2β-hydroxynagilactone E (7b).(144,145) The (3S,4R,5R,6S,7R,8R,10S,14R) absolute configuration was proposed originally by analysis of the ECD spectrum of NGL E(143) and confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments for 7b and 1-deoxy-2β-hydroxynagilactone A (7c), of which the absolute configuration was determined by analysis of the Flack parameter [0.06 (3)] for 7b and the graphite-monochromated Cu Kα radiation for 7c.(145,146)
    NGL E was found to be cytotoxic against P-388 murine leukemia cells (IC50 0.72 μM) and showed moderate growth inhibitory activity in A549 (IC50 5.2 μM) and NCI-H1975 (IC50 3.6 μM) human NSCLC cells (Figure 15).(144,147) It also inhibited TGF-β1-induced EMT, migration, and invasion in NSCLC A549 cells.(148) An in vivo study demonstrated that lung tumor growth was suppressed significantly when male CB-17/SCID mice (14–16 g) were inoculated by A549 cells (1 week) and treated (i.p.) daily with NGL E (10 mg/kg) for 3 weeks, with no obvious adverse effects being observed in the test mice.(149) Mechanistic studies indicated that NGL E inhibits proliferation in A549 and NCI-H1975 cells through induction of G2 phase cell cycle arrest and caspase-dependent cell apoptosis, and it decreases the protein levels of cyclin B1, as well as the nuclear localization in these cells.(147) As a potential protein synthesis inhibitor, NGL E targets RIOK2 [RIO (right open reading frame) kinase 2] to inhibit lung tumor growth.(149)
    Investigation of the cytotoxicity of NGL E and its analogues showed that various substituents seem essential in this regard. Removal of the C-3 hydroxy group [e.g., as in nagilactone G (7d)] increased slightly the cytotoxicity of NGL E (7), but introducing further hydroxy groups at the C-1 and C-16 positions [e.g., as in makilactone I (7a)] resulted in the activity being decreased,(144) indicating that these hydroxy groups might not be required for maximal cytotoxicity. A switch of the hydroxy group from C-3 to C-2 [e.g., as in 3-deoxy-2β-hydroxynagilactone E (7b)] potentiated activity, but this did not change greatly when the pyrone ring was altered to a dihydropyrone unit followed by a replacement of the C-17/C-18 epoxy group with a C-7 hydroxy group [e.g., 1-deoxy-2β-hydroxynagilactone A (7c)].(145,146,150)
    In addition, the activity of 7 against A549 cells was improved slightly by hydroxylation at the C-16 position [16-hydroxynagilactone E (7e)], but such a change as exemplified by 3-deoxy-2β,16-dihydroxynagilactone E (7f) reduced the potency of 7b.(145,147,150) However, substitution of a glucose unit at the C-16 hydroxy group of 7e [e.g., 16-O-β-d-glucopyranosylnagilactone E (7g)] resulted in the cytotoxicity being abolished for all of human A431 epidermoid carcinoma, A549 NSCLC, and U87 glioma cells (Figure 15).(150) While the C-7/C-8 epoxy group seems not critical for the mediation of the cytotoxicity of these norditerpene dilactones, as suggested by the similar cytotoxic potencies against P-388 cells observed for 7d and nagilactone F (7h) and those against HeLa cells for 7b and 2β-hydroxynagilactone F (7i), introduction of a 2β-hydroxy group still leads to the activity of 7h being retained (Figure 16).(144,145,151) Replacing the C-ring with a pyrone unit plus changing the 2β-hydroxy group to a C-1/C-2 epoxy moiety followed by introduction of hydroxy group at the C-3 and C-7 positions [e.g., nagilactone C (7j)] diminished the activity of 7i considerably.(145)
    Interestingly, removal of the C-17 methyl group from 7h [e.g., makilactone A (7k), a C18-bisnorditerpene dilactone] or further substitutions of the C-2/C-3 and C-7/C-8 epoxy and C-3 hydroxy groups [e.g., as in inumakilactone B (7l)] did not change greatly the resultant potency. However, addition of a water molecule at the Δ15(16) double bond [inumakilactone A (7m)] decreased potency, while further introduction of a C-16 hydroxy group resulted in formation of an inactive compound, makilactone M (7n) (Figure 16).(145) These observations indicate that the 17-methyl and 1,2- and 7,8-epoxy groups are not required for nagilactone F (7h) to mediate its cytotoxicity, while the introduction of a 15,16-diol unit abrogated this type of activity. Thus, modification at the C-14 side chain could be important to improve on the cancer cell cytotoxic potencies of the nagilactone derivatives.
    Therefore, it is pertinent to note that wentilactone A (7o), a C16-tetranorlabdane diterpene dilactone derived from the fungus Aspergillus wentii (Trichocomaceae), with the C-14 side chain being absent, exhibited weak cytotoxicity toward human cancer cells (Figure 16).(152,153) Wentilactone A (7o) was found to induce apoptosis and G2/M arrest in human NCI H460 large-cell and NCI H446 small-cell lung cancer cells via the Ras/Raf/ERK pathway, targeting HRas-guanosine-5′-triphosphate (GTP). Lung tumor growth was inhibited when five-week-old male BALB/c athymic mice were inoculated with NCI H460 and NCI H446 cells and treated daily (i.p.) with wentilactone A (5 mg/kg) for 20 days after solid tumors appeared.(154)
    Investigation of the cytotoxicity of wentilactone A (7o) and its close analogues, asperolide E (7p), wentilactone B (7q), and asperolide A (7r), showed that all of these tetranorditerpene dilactones exhibited comparable low activity, with IC50 values being in the range 10–70 μM (Figure 16).(153,155) This indicates that the C-1/C-2 epoxy group and the position of the hydroxy group connected to the A-ring do not affect greatly the cytotoxicity of these compounds. Similar to wentilactone A (7o), wentilactone B (7q), a tetranorditerpene dilactone isolated from Aspergillus wentii,(152,156) induced efficiently apoptosis in SMMC-7721 human hepatoma cells to suppress cell proliferation, and it also inhibited migration of SMMC-7721 cells by interacting with the cell-surface receptors, CD44 and EGFR.(157) Liver tumor growth was inhibited significantly when nude mice were inoculated by SMMC-7721 cells (1 week) and treated (i.p.) once every 2 days with wentilactone B (7q, 10 mg/kg) for 3 weeks, and no obvious adverse effects were observed in these mice.(158) Mechanistically, wentilactone B binds directly to Ras–GTP to induce cell cycle arrest at the G2 phase and mitochondrial-related apoptosis in SMMC-7721 cells through the Ras/Raf/ERK and Ras/Raf/JNK signaling pathways.(158)
    Asperolide A (7r) suppressed lung tumor growth when six-week-old BALB/c male athymic mice were inoculated with NCI-H460 human large-cell lung cancer cells and treated (i.v.) with asperolide A (5 mg/kg) once every 2 days for 20 days after solid tumors were formed. No obvious changes were observed in the body weights of the treated mice.(159) This dilactone (7r) mediates its antitumor activity by inhibition of cell-cycle progression at the G2/M phase through decreasing the levels of CDC2, cdc25c, and cyclin B, as well as by induction of G2/M arrest mediated by p53-dependent p21 induction and regulated by the Ras/Raf/MEK/ERK signaling pathway.(159)
    Investigation of the cytotoxicity reported for nagilactone E (NGL E, 7) and its analogues indicates that a switch of the hydroxy group from C-3 to C-2 potentiated the cytotoxicity of 7 against A549 cells, but introducing a glucopyranosyl group at the C-17 position resulted in such activity being abolished (Figure 17).
    The RIO family of atypical serine protein kinases has been characterized recently based on the gene RIO, with its representatives occurring widely among organisms, from archaea to humans. The ubiquitous presence and enzymatic activity involving ribosome biogenesis, a fundamental process in all living cells, suggest that RIOK could be novel targets for drug design.(160) More recently, RIOK2 was found to be highly expressed in A549, H1299, H1975 and H1650 NSCLC cancer cells and tissues from NSCLC patients, and the expression of RIOK2 and NOB1 (Nin one binding) was associated significantly with tumor and lymph node metastasis and differentiation and patient survival rates, suggesting that these proteins could be potential targets for NSCLC therapy.(161)
    NGL E (7) targeted RIOK2 to inhibit protein synthesis to subsequently suppress A549 NSCLC tumor growth in mice.(149) Treatment (i.p.) with all of compounds 7, 7o, 7q, and 7r did not result in any toxicity in mice,(149,154,158,159) and 3-deoxy-2β,16-dihydroxynagilactone E (7f) mediates its cancer cell cytotoxicity through inhibiting JAK2/STAT3 signaling.(162) All of the analogues of 7 presented herein are natural products, and novel agents produced from the synthetic derivatization of NGL E (7) could contribute to the control of cancer by inhibition of tumor metastasis, and targeting RIOK2. In this regard, introducing a triazole unit as used in the modification of GKL B (5) at the C-14 position of 7 might enhance such a possibility.(114)

    Triptolide

    Triptolide (TPL, 8), along with its analogues tripdiolide (8a) and triptonide (8b), which are 18(4 → 3) abeo-abietane-type diterpenoid triepoxide lactones, were isolated originally from the roots of Tripterygium wilfordii Hook.f. (Celastraceae), a traditional Chinese medicine, namely, “Lei Gong Teng” (Thunder God Vine), by Kupchan and his associates at University of Virginia in 1972. Subsequently, the complete structure and stereochemistry were determined by analysis of its single-crystal X-ray diffraction data and those of 8a (Figure 18), and the consistent absolute configuration [(5S,7S,8S,9S,10S,11S,12S,13R,14R) for 8 and (3S,5S,7S,8S,9S,10S,11S,12S,13R,14R) for 8a] was also defined by the Hamilton’s R-factor ratio test and the measurement of intensity differences in selected Friedel pairs of reflections.(163,164) In their early investigation, both 8 and 8a were found to show potent cytotoxicity against KB human oral epidermoid carcinoma cells (IC50 0.27–2.8 nM) and significant antileukemic activity against the L1210 and P-388 murine leukemias at a dose of 0.1 mg/kg.(163)
    Similar to the traditional medicinal use of the roots of T. wilfordii for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, cancer, and other inflammatory and autoimmune diseases, TPL exhibits analogous bioactivities in the laboratory, targeting the IL-6/8, MMPs, PGE2, and TLR2/4 through the p38 and ERK, MAPK, and NF-κB pathways.(165) Previously, the potential therapeutic effects of TPL toward human malignancies by the induction of cancer cell apoptosis and inhibition of cell invasion and migration and tumor vascularization have been reviewed in 2018.(166) The regulation of pro- and antiapoptotic proteins by TPL to induce breast cancer cell apoptosis through interacting with Akt, ERK, FAK, NF-κB, VEGF and other related signaling pathways to suppress breast tumor growth,(167) as well its antipancreatic cancer properties in different experimental models through the angiogenic, apoptosis, and autophagic pathways, also have been summarized in 2017.(168) As an update to these reviews, the present perspective article focuses on the structural requirements and molecular targets of TPL to provide important indicators for the design of further TPL-type antitumor agents.
    TPL exhibited potent cytotoxicity against B16F10 mouse melanoma and human BGC-823 gastric, HCT116 colon, HepG2 liver, and NCI-H1650 bronchoalveolar cancer cells, with IC50 values in the range 2–15 nM.(169) It decreased the viability of human Panc-1 pancreatic and PC3 prostate cancer cells, with IC50 values being around 200 and 43 nM, respectively.(170,171) Also, TPL induced apoptosis and showed cytotoxicity in CD133+/CD44+ colon CSCs and inhibited cell migration.(172)
    In in vivo studies, TPL suppressed breast tumor xenograft growth when 4–5-week-old female BALB/c athymic mice were inoculated with MDA-MB-231 human breast cancer cells and treated (i.p.) daily with TPL (0.15 mg/kg) for 2 weeks, after solid tumors occurred.(173) Colon tumor growth was inhibited significantly, and the life span of the test animals was increased when ICR-1 mice bearing colon tumors induced by azoxymethane (AOM) and dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) were treated daily with TPL (0.2 mg/kg, by gavage) for 4 weeks.(174) Also, ovarian tumor growth was inhibited when Balb/c-nu mice were inoculated by SKOV3 human ovarian cancer cells (1 week) and treated (i.p.) daily with TPL (0.15 mg/kg) for 2 weeks.(175)
    Furthermore, TPL has demonstrated an ability to circumvent cancer cell resistance, targeting ATP-binding cassette transporters, apoptosis induction, tumor suppressors, oncogenic factors, the RNA polymerase II complex, CSC, and TME.(176) For example, TPL sensitized SKOV3/DDP human cisplatin (DDP)-resistant ovarian cancer cells to treatment with DDP by inhibiting Akt.(177) It enhanced the sensitivity of Panc-1 human pancreatic cancer cells to gemcitabine (GEM) treatment by targeting inhibition of TLR4/NF-κB signaling.(178) A combined treatment with TPL and a tyrosine kinase inhibitor enhanced synergistically apoptosis in H1975 but not H1299 human NSCLC cells, due to partial inhibition of the EGFR/Akt pathway.(179) As one of the most serious challenges to a successful cancer chemotherapeutic regimen, MDR is a comprehensive result of multiple complex cellular process, and focusing only on one target is rarely effective in resolving this problem. TPL inhibits the resistance of cancer cells to cancer chemotherapy through multiple mechanisms, and it or its derivatives could thus be promising clinically if used in combination with existing anticancer drugs.
    Over the period of 2016–2020, numerous investigations have demonstrated that TPL mediates its antitumor activity through interacting with multiple molecular targets, including the ERK/Akt, HIF-1α, Hsp70, MAPK, c-Myc, and NF-κB signaling pathways.(166−168,180,181) Of these, its stimulation of autophagy to induce neuroblastoma, leukemia, and colon, lung, and pancreatic cancer cell death and inhibition of Hsp70 have been investigated extensively.(180,182) As an evolutionarily conserved intracellular catabolic process to converge on the delivery of cargos to the lysosome for degradation and recycling, the autophagic pathway is a widely investigated anticancer target. In addition, Hsp70 is a cancer cell survival promoter, and inhibition of this protein can kill cancer cells effectively. The functionality of TPL as both an autophagy modulator and a Hsp70 inhibitor in mesothelioma cells indicates that this diterpene triepoxide could be a potential candidate for the treatment of malignant mesothelioma.(182,183)
    To improve on its antitumor parameters, many TPL-targeted delivery systems have been developed, including conjugation of TPL to a sugar, peptide, oligonucleotide, or antibody ligand, or encapsulation of TPL with well-designed nanovehicle.(184) More recently, TPL-loaded tumor acid-triggered micelles that were modified by a CRPPR peptide delivery system were prepared, which increased the therapeutic effects of TPL against pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, one of the most devastating malignancies, and reduced the damage to the main animal organs that resulted from TPL treatment.(185)
    Although TPL has shown potent cytotoxicity at nanomolar concentrations and is a promising sensitizer to circumvent anticancer drug resistance, exposure to this diterpenoid may result in membrane damage, mitochondrial disruption, metabolism dysfunction, endoplasmic reticulum and oxidative stress, apoptosis and autophagy on the cellular level, as well as injury to various organs, including the liver, kidney, testes, ovary, and heart in test animals.(186) These adverse effects have hindered the further clinical development of TPL, and thus various synthetic modifications of TPL have been conducted. As a foundation for further work, TPL has been synthesized, using tetralone, L-abietic acid, and/or L-dehydroabietic acid as starting materials and by processing Diels–Alder or metal-catalyzed reactions or polyene cyclization to construct the core structure.(187) These synthetic approaches have not only resolved the problem of the lack natural abundant supply of TPL but also form a basis for SAR investigations, synthetic optimization, and further development of this antitumor diterpene triepoxide.
