    Previous SAR investigations have shown that a hydrogen-bonded hydroxy group at the C-14 position, the three epoxy groups, and the α,β-unsaturated-five-membered lactone unit (D ring) are the key groups for TPL to mediate its antitumor activity.(188) Following these conclusions, the water solubility and cytotoxicity of TPL was enhanced by derivatization at the 14β-hydroxy group, and its toxicity was reduced while retaining the immunosuppressive and antitumor potential by introduction of suitable groups at the C-5 and C-6 positions.(188,189) As summarized in a 2019 review article, several of these derivatives and TPL itself showed a broad spectrum of activity against a variety of types of cancer cells through multiple pathways that are commonly deregulated in cancer, such as apoptosis, autophagy, EMT, and regulation of gene expression.(190) Additional SAR studies have suggested that the C-13 position could be another site for potential modification,(191) as indicated by the diminished cytotoxicity observed when a hydroxy group was introduced at the C-15 position of TPL [e.g., as in the plant-derived triptolidenol or 15-hydroxytriptolide (8c)], and by the inactive natural product analogue, triptriolide (8d) that contains a 12,13-diol rather than a 12,13-epoxy group. Also, the cytotoxicity of 8 was decreased when an additional C-2 hydroxy group was introduced [e.g., tripdiolide (8a)], suggesting that C-2 could be another potential position for the modification of TPL (Figure 18).(192) Furthermore, the cytotoxicity of TPL was decreased when an extra epoxy group was introduced at the C-14 position [e.g., the synthetic derivative, (14S)-14,21-epoxytriptolide (8e)],(170) indicating that TPL might be modified at this position, and a tetra-epoxy system is probably not required. However, the cytotoxic potency of TPL was found not to change greatly when the C-14 hydroxy group was oxidized to a carbonyl group [e.g., triptonide (8b)].(193)
    Different from TPL (8) that targets the Wnt3a-CM-induced β-catenin protein, triptonide (8b) did not downregulate this protein, while it inhibited effectively canonical Wnt/β-catenin signaling by acting at the C-terminal transcription domain of β-catenin or its associated nuclear component. This indicates that 8b inhibits Wnt/β-catenin signaling through a mechanism different from that of 8. Abnormal activation of canonical Wnt/β-catenin signaling is implicated in cancer, and thus triptonide (8b) was found to induce apoptosis in Wnt-dependent human RKO and SW480 colon cancer cells and thus to inhibit cell growth, with IC50 values of 15 nM and 17 nM, respectively.(194) In addition, triptonide (8b) showed potent cytotoxicity toward AGS, HGC-27, MGC-803, N87, and SGC-7901 human gastric cancer cells (IC50 < 20 nM),(195) AsPC-1, BxPC-3, CFPAC-1, Panc-1, PaTu8988, and SW1990 human pancreatic cancer cells (IC50 < 20 nM),(196) DU-145, LNCaP, and PC3 human prostate cancer cells (IC50 10–12 nM),(193) and Raji and Jurkat human lymphoma cells (IC50 4–6 nM).(197)
    In animal models, triptonide (8b) suppressed effectively gastric tumor growth and gastric cancer cell metastasis to the lung when six-week-old female BALB/c nude mice were inoculated by HGC-27 cells followed by daily treatments (i.p.) with 8b (5 mg/kg) for 38 days. The tumors in four of the five tumor-bearing mice treated with 8b disappeared completely, with those in the other mouse being reduced markedly, with no obvious body weight changes occurring among the test animals.(195) Pancreatic tumor growth was inhibited effectively, with the inhibition rate being 97.5%, when eight-week-old female NOD/SCID mice were inoculated by PaTu8988 cells followed by daily treatments (i.p.) with 8b (5 mg/kg) for 60 days, with no significant changes observed in the mouse body weights.(196) Also, triptonide exerted a strong antilymphoma activity when eight-week-old female NOD/SCID mice were inoculated by Raji cells followed by daily treatments (i.p.) with triptonide (8b) (5 mg/kg) for 35 days, without any evidence of toxicity being obtained.(197)
    Mechanistic investigations have indicated that triptonide (8b) activates the tumor-suppressive MEKK4-MKK4-p38 MAPK pathway in pancreatic cancer cells and mediates antiprostate tumor activity through inhibiting mTOR signaling.(193,196) In turn, it suppressed effectively gastric tumor growth and metastasis through inhibition of the oncogenic Notch1 and NF-κB signaling pathways, and it induced colon cancer cell apoptosis by targeting Wnt/β-catenin signaling.(194,195) Moreover, triptonide was found to repress oncogenic Lyn expression, Lyn phosphorylation, and the Lyn downstream ERK and AKT signal pathways in lymphoma cells. Overexpression of Lyn, Lck/Yes novel tyrosine kinase or v-yes-1 Yamaguchi sarcoma viral related oncogene homologue, promotes lymphoma cell proliferation and metastasis. Thus, Lyn has recently become an important target for novel antilymphoma drug discovery. Triptonide targets Lyn to mediate its antileukemic activity, suggesting that this diterpene lactone may function as a probe to explore other related new targets for Lyn-targeted lymphoma treatment.(197)
    In addition, a TPL conjugate has been synthesized, namely, CX-23 (8f, Figure 18), which contains a quinone unit attached to its C-14 hydroxy group through a linker, propionic acid, with reference to NAD(P)H:quinone oxidoreductase 1 (NQO1) that catalyzes the two-electron reduction of other substrates and is overexpressed in HCC. Molecular modeling showed that the quinone of CX-23 binds to NQO1 at its active site and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), with the TPL component itself kept outside the substrate binding pocket, indicating that the interaction between the quinone unit of CX-23 and NQO1 is not affected by the TPL moiety.(198) In vitro studies showed that CX-23 inhibited HepG2 HCC cell growth (IC50 54 nM), which is comparable in potency with that of TPL, but such activity was found to be lost partially when cells were treated with a combination of CX-23 and dicoumarol, a NQO1 inhibitor, indicating that CX-23 may depend on NQO1 to mediate its cytotoxicity.(198)
    In an in vivo study, hepatoma growth was inhibited significantly when 7–9 week-old female Balb/c nude mice were inoculated by HepG2 cells, and solid tumors were formed. The tumor-bearing mice were treated (i.p.) daily with TPL (0.2 mg/kg) or CX-23 (0.3 mg/kg) for 15 days. No obvious toxic effects were observed in mice treated with CX-23, but an abnormal renal function was indicated in the TPL treatment group from the increased levels of creatinine and BUN when compared with those of the control or the CX-23 treatment group. Therefore, CX-23 could be a promising lead for the discovery of anti-HCC TPLs with reduced renal toxicity, and NQO1 may serve as a targeted delivery system to release CX-23 in HCC cells.(198)
    When a furoxan-based NO-donating moiety was introduced directly at the C-14 hydroxy group of TPL, a novel triptolide/furoxan hybrid molecule (8g) was synthesized. This hybrid exhibited cytotoxicity against a small panel of cancer cell lines, with IC50 values in the nanomolar range, which was less potent cytotoxic than PTL itself. In a melanoma xenograft mouse model, tumor growth was inhibited significantly when female C57BL/6 mice (18–20 g) were inoculated by B16F10 mouse melanoma cells and treated daily with 8g (0.3 mg/kg, orally) for 20 days, after solid tumors occurred. Importantly, 8g showed evidence of low acute toxicity [median lethal dose (LD50) = 160.9 mg/kg], which was decreased up to 200-fold when compared with TPL itself (LD50 0.79 mg/kg), demonstrating that the toxicity of TPL can be lowered greatly through modification of its C-14 hydroxy group.(169)
    Following this, a water-soluble derivative of TPL, 14-O-phosphonooxymethyltriptolide disodium salt, namely, Minnelide (8h), was synthesized, with an estimated approximately two-year shelf life (t90) observed for hydrolysis to occur.(171,199) This novel TPL prodrug was found to decrease the viability of S2-013, MiaPaCa-2, and Panc-1 human pancreatic cancer cells in the presence of phosphatase, with IC50 values being around 200 nM, comparable with those of TPL.(171) An initial in vivo study showed that Minnelide (8h) inhibited pancreatic tumor growth when 4–6-week-old female athymic mice were inoculated with MIA PaCa-2 cells, and the solid tumor-bearing mice were treated (i.p.) with TPL (0.2 mg/kg, daily), or Minnelide (0.1–0.6 mg/kg, twice a day) for 60 days, followed by 30 days of absence of treatment. Also, the antipancreatic tumor efficacy of 8h was found to be more effective than that of gemcitabine, a first-line FDA-approved pancreatic cancer chemotherapeutic agent, when 4- to 6-week-old female athymic mice bearing MIA PaCa-2 pancreatic tumors were treated (i.p.) with gemcitabine (100 mg/kg, twice a week) or Minnelide (0.28 mg/kg, daily) for 60 days. Further toxicity studies using this same animal model showed that Minnelide was not toxic after a 29-day treatment at a dose of 0.3 mg/kg (i.p.), and no overt signs of toxicity were observed over a 385-day treatment at a dose of 0.42 mg/kg (i.p.).(171)
    The potential antipancreatic and antihepatic tumor activities of Minnelide (8h) have been described in a previous review in 2015.(200) Both pancreatic adenocarcinoma and hepatoma are among the most lethal malignancies, with no effective treatments available, with the 5-year survival rate of pancreatic cancer being extremely poor. Thus, Minnelide could become a novel chemotherapeutic agent for the treatment of both pancreatic and liver cancer.(171,200) In addition, Minnelide has shown promising inhibitory effects on other types of tumor models. For example, colon tumor growth was inhibited when 7- to 9-week-old female athymic nude mice were inoculated with HT-29 human colon cancer cells and treated (i.p.) daily with Minnelide (0.3 mg/kg) for 4 weeks, after solid tumors occurred. No toxic signs were observed in mice.(199) HPV-positive head-and-neck tumor progression was decreased effectively when 4–6-week-old female nude mice bearing the xenografts developed from inoculation of UM-SCC 47 human papillomavirus (HPV) head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) cells or young adult SCID mice implanted with human oropharyngeal HPV-positive tumors were treated (i.p.) daily with Minnelide (0.42 mg/kg) for 6 weeks.(201) Also, lung tumor growth was slowed significantly when 4–6-week-old nu/nu nude mice were inoculated by A549 NSCLC or NCI-H460 large cell lung cancer cells (5 days) and treated (i.p.) daily with Minnelide (0.42 mg/kg) for 28 days, with no obvious toxic effects observed in mice.(202) In addition, survival in two orthotopic ovarian tumor models was increased significantly when 6-week-old female athymic mice were inoculated by human platinum-sensitive (A2780) or -resistant (C200) ovarian cancer cells (7–12 days) and treated (i.p.) daily with Minnelide (0.42 and 0.6 mg/kg in A2780 and C200 animal models, respectively) for 28 days.(203)
    The androgen receptor (AR) is expressed throughout prostate cancer progression, and androgen-deprivation therapy (ADT) has been a key treatment of prostate cancer, although this treatment may eventually fail, owing to the occurrence of castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC). Encouragingly, tumors derived from CRPC cells were found to be sensitive to Minnelide, which showed superior anti-CRPC activity when compared with docetaxel and enzalutamide, two standard prostate cancer chemotherapy drugs, when 4–6-week-old athymic male nude mice were inoculated with 22RV1 human CRPC cells, and solid tumors were formed. The tumor-bearing mice were treated with Minnelide (0.21 mg/kg, daily, i.p.), docetaxel (10 mg/kg, weekly, i.p.), or enzalutamide (10 mg/kg, daily, oral gavage) for 5 weeks. This indicates that Minnelide is promising for further evaluation against other AR-dependent prostate cancers for the potential control of CRPC.(204) This derivative also exerts a potent antileukemic effect, as a result of which the tumor burden was reduced dramatically when NRGS mice were inoculated by THP-1 AML cells expressed by the luciferase reporter gene and treated (i.p.) daily with Minnelide (0.1 mg/kg) for 45 days.(205)
    Similar to the parent compound, Minnelide (8h) targets several molecular signaling pathways to repress tumor progression, including inducing apoptosis to slow NSCLC tumor growth, reducing the expression of androgen receptor and its splice variants to inhibit androgen dependent castration-resistant prostate tumor growth, and activating wild-type p53 to retard HNSCC growth.(201,202,205)
    Thus far, Minnelide has been tested in several clinical trials for the treatment of cancer patients. A phase I, multicenter, open-label, dose-escalation, safety, pharmacokinetic, and pharmacodynamic study of Minnelide given (i.v.) daily for 21 days followed by 7 days off-schedule in patients with advanced gastrointestinal tumors from August 2013 to December 2016 has been completed, from which the MTD and DLT of Minnelide were established, with the dose for a future phase II protocol determined (Study of Minnelide in Patients With Advanced GI Tumors, https://ichgcp.net/clinical-trials-registry/NCT01927965). Also, a phase I, multicenter, open-label, dose-escalation, safety, pharmacokinetic, and pharmacodynamic study of Minnelide capsules given (orally) alone or in combination with protein-bound paclitaxel to patients with advanced solid tumors, including breast, colorectal, gastric, pancreatic, metastatic prostate, and stomach tumors is recruiting from October 2017 to December 2021 (https://ichgcp.net/clinical-trials-registry/NCT03129139).
    Even though a very recent phase I pilot study of Minnelide designed as a novel Hsp70 inhibitor in adult patients with relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia was withdrawn (https://ichgcp.net/clinical-trials-registry/NCT03347994), a phase I/Ib dose escalation study of Minnelide in relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia to determine its safety and recommended phase II oral dose in AML is underway (https://ichgcp.net/clinical-trials-registry/NCT03760523). Following these phase I clinical trials, a phase II, international open label trial of Minnelide in patients with refractory pancreatic cancer from April 2017 to May 2020 is currently active but not recruiting, in which Minnelide is being administered at the dose of 0.67 mg/m2 as a 30 min infusion intravenously daily on days 1–21 of each cycle followed by a 7-day rest period (https://ichgcp.net/clinical-trials-registry/NCT03117920).
    Thus far, the diterpene triepoxide lactone triptolide (TPL, 8) has been investigated extensively for its antitumor effects, including its activity toward cancer cells and tumor xenograft models, and for the mechanisms of action involved, MDR reversal, synergy with other modes of cancer chemotherapy, and the development of synthetic derivatives and novel delivery systems to improve on potency. SAR investigations indicate that introducing a hydroxy group at the C-2 or C-15 position decreases cytotoxic potency of 8, while substitution of a phosphonooxymethyl group at the C-14 position improves the antitumor potential of 8 (Figure 19). The TPL prodrug, Minnelide, has been developed successfully for phase I and phase II clinical trial applications, which indicates also that introducing a water-soluble phosphonooxymethyl group could be a promising strategy for developing other NPs as novel anticancer agents.

    Triterpene Lactones

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The triterpenoids are a large group of natural products derived from C30 precursors and are of interest for their diverse structures and bioactivities, particularly in terms of their antitumor potential.(13,206) Of these, pristimerin, a quinone methide triterpenoid isolated from species of the Celastraceae and Hippocrateaceae plant families, has been investigated extensively for its potential anticancer activities that involve apoptosis, autophagy, migration and invasion, vasculogenesis, and drug resistance, by targeting the cyclins, MAPK, microRNA, NF-κB, PI3K/Akt/mTOR, and ROS pathways.(207) Bardoxolone methyl (CDDO-Me or RTA 402), a synthetic oleanane-type triterpenoid, has reached a clinical trial for the potential treatment of cancer.(13) In addition, several triterpene lactones that contain either a five-membered γ-lactone or a six-membered δ-lactone group have been found to show promising antitumor properties, including bruceantin (BRC, 9), dichapetalin A (DCT, 10), and limonin (LMN 11), as detailed in the following paragraphs.

    Bruceantin

    Quassinoids (simaroubolides) are a group of degraded natural products derived from tetracyclic triterpenoids and comprised mainly of the C18, C19, C20, C22, C25, and C26 skeletal types. These NPs have been purified mostly from plants in the family Simaroubaceae and found to exhibit multiple potent bioactivities.(208,209) Of these, bruceantin (BRC, 9), a C20-quassinoid containing a δ-lactone unit between C-7 and C-16, was isolated originally as one of the major antileukemic components from Brucea antidysenterica Mill. (Simaroubaceae).(210) The (5R,7R,8R,9R,10S,11R,12S,13S,14S,15R) absolute configuration of BRC was determined by comparison of its spectroscopic data with those of its closely similar natural product analogues, brusatol (9a) and bruceine A (9b) (Figure 20), for which their complete structures were established using single-crystal X-ray diffraction data.(211,212)
    As reviewed previously in 2004, BRC down-regulates c-myc to exhibit activity against hematological malignancies.(213) It showed potent cytotoxicity toward HL-60 human leukemia cells (IC50 = 40 nM)(214) and inhibited human HCT116 (IC50 = 67 nM) and HT-29 (IC50 = 22 nM) colon and HeLa cervical (IC50 = 29 nM) cancer cell growth effectively.(215,216) At a low concentration (25 nM), BRC suppressed the proliferation of human multiple myeloma stem cells, which are highly resistant to conventional cancer chemotherapeutic agents.(217) It was also potently cytotoxic against the KB-VIN, KB-7d, and KB-CPT human MDR cancer cell lines.(218)
    An in vivo study showed that leukemia was regressed significantly when 13-week-old female severe-combined immunodeficiency (SCID) mice were inoculated with RPMI 8226 human leukemia cells (46 days) and treated (i.p.) with BRC (2.5 mg/kg, every 3 days) for 17 days.(219) Mechanistic investigations showed that BRC exhibited cytotoxicity toward human cancer cells through down-regulation of c-Myc(213,219) and inhibition of STAT3.(216) It suppressed multiple myeloma stem cell proliferation through the Notch pathway.(217)
    In a phase I clinical trial, 18 patients with metastatic cancer divided into separate normal to mildly abnormal liver functions and hepatic dysfunction groups were treated with BRC (infused intravenously for 3 h) at doses ranging from 1 to 3.6 mg/m2 per day for 5 days. The dose-limiting toxicity found was hypotension that occurred in the abnormal liver function group, and an individualized therapy was recommended.(220) A Phase II study was carried out in 22 patients with advanced malignant melanoma, who were infused with BRC at a dose of 5.5 mg/m2 over 2 h, with the infusions repeated weekly for 4 weeks and then resumed after a two-week break. The treatment was continued for four full courses if a complete response occurred or as long as acceptable toxicity permitted for the partial responses. However, patients were removed from the study if progression of the disease occurred. From this phase II study, no objective cancer regressions were observed, and thus BRC was not suggested to be of use for the systemic therapy of melanoma, either as a single agent or in combination with other cytotoxic drugs.(221) In turn, other clinical trials for BRC were terminated,(213) and scientific interest has shifted to the development of BRC analogues as possible antitumor agents.
    Earlier SAR studies indicated that a substituent at the C-15 position is important for the mediation of the antileukemic activity of BRC, of which both the length and presence of the C-1′–C-3′ α,ß-unsaturated carbonyl unit contribute greatly to the resultant activity.(222) Thus, bruceantin (BRC, 9) and brusatol (9a), which each contain a C-15 α,ß-unsaturated ester, were found to be more potent than their naturally occurring analogues, bruceine A (9b) or bruceine B (9c).
    Compound 9 was more active than 9a, and 9b showed a more potent activity than 9c (Figure 20),(214−216,222,223) indicating that a large C-15 substituent might be preferable in this regard. Comparison of the activity of 9 with that of its natural analogue, bruceine C (9d), implied that substitution of a hydroxy group at the C-5′ position of 9 decreased cytotoxic potency against HCT116 human colon cancer cells, but acetylation of this hydroxy group improved such activity greatly, as shown by bruceantinol (9e).(216) However, changing the location of the α,β-unsaturated carbonyl group along the C-1–C-4 positions followed by glucosylation at the hydroxy group at C-2 resulted in the activity abolished, as exhibited by the naturally occurring bruceantinoside A (9f), bruceoside A (9g), and yadanzioside A (9h) (Figure 20).(223)
    A more detailed SAR study of brusatol (9a) and its synthetic derivatives and their activity against P-388 murine leukemia cells indicated that the length of the C-21 ester side chain has a slight effect on the cytotoxic activity, but either methylation or removal of the C-3 hydroxy group decreases activity markedly.(224) These trends have been confirmed by cell growth inhibition screening against the NCI 60-cell line panel and by using MCF-7 and MDA-MB-231 breast cancer cells, but the direction of the ether bridge either from C-11 to C-20 or from C-13 to C-20 did not affect the overall inhibitory effects on cancer cell growth (Figures 20 and 21),(225,226) However, cleavage of C-2 and C-3, which forms a 2,3-dicarboxylic acid unit, resulted in an inactive natural product, javanic acid A (9i, IC50 > 10 μM toward all the cancer cell lines tested),(227) while modification of the C-2–C-4 enone group seems not to affect the activity very much, as indicated by the comparable cytotoxicity observed for natural products bruceine D (9j) and bruceine H (9k), as well for the plant-derived bruceanols D (9l), F (9m), and E (9n) (Figure 21).(227,228)
    On the basis of the SAR investigations for BRC (9), the ester unit connected at the C-15 position seems important for this compound to mediate its cytotoxicity. Either removal of the dimethyl group from C-5′ or introducing a hydroxy group at this position decreases its cytotoxicity (Figure 22).
    Interestingly, one of the analogues of BRC, brusatol (9a), was found to show more potent cytotoxic activity against several pancreatic cancer cell lines than the positive control, camptothecin (CPT).(223) As reviewed previously in 2019, brusatol (9a) exhibited cytotoxicity toward human leukemia and solid adenocarcinoma, colon and hepatic cancer cell lines, as well as mammospheres.(229) It inhibited several short-lived proteins in A549 human lung cancer cells to overcome potentially chemoresistance,(230) while it decreased the viability of Bel7404, Hep3B, Huh7, LM3 human liver cancer cells and suppressed cell proliferation and invasion and migration capacity in Bel7404 cells.(231) Also, it induced BXPC-3, Panc-1, and PATU-8988 human pancreatic cancer cell apoptosis, and abrogated gemcitabine-induced Nrf2 activation to potentiate the gemcitabine-induced growth inhibition in these cancer cells.(232)
    In vivo studies have shown that brusatol inhibited significantly the growth of hepatocellular tumors when 6-week-old BALB/C-nu/nu nude mice were inoculated by Bel7404 cells (14 days) and treated (i.p.) with brusatol (9a) (2 mg/kg, every 2 days) for 28 days, with no significant toxic effects being observed in mice. Immunohistochemical analysis demonstrated that Ki67, MMP2, and MMP9 expression levels in the Bel7404 xenograft tissues were diminished, indicating that brusatol reduced tumor growth by inhibiting proliferation and tumor cell invasion and metastasis.(231) It also enhanced the antitumor activity of gemcitabine when 4–6-week-old male BALB/c homozygous nude mice were inoculated by Panc-1 cancer cells (1 week) and treated (i.p.) with brusatol (2 mg/kg, daily), gemcitabine (100 mg/kg, twice a week), or brusatol (2 mg/kg, daily) plus gemcitabine (100 mg/kg, twice a week) for 26 days. However, considerably lower body weights were observed in the nude mice treated with brusatol plus gemcitabine, demonstrating that this combination treatment exerted adverse effects in these test animals.(232)
    The Nrf2 pathway is a major target for brusatol to mediate its antitumor activity. Activation of Nrf2 supports cell survival under detrimental environments to promote cancer formation and to contribute to chemoresistance, and, hence, suppressing Nrf2 can inhibit tumor progression and enhance the effectiveness of cancer treatments.(233,234) Brusatol inhibited the Nrf2 signaling pathway effectively to augment the antitumor effects of gemcitabine,(232) and it also sensitized cancer cells and xenografts to cisplatin and increased the chemotherapeutic efficacy of cisplatin through specific inhibition of Nrf2-dependent cellular defense mechanisms.(233) Through inhibition of Nrf2, brusatol showed dual antihepatitis C virus (HCV) and hepatic cancer cell growth inhibitory activities, as well enhancing the dual effects on sorafenib.(235) These results suggest that brusatol can be used as an adjuvant chemotherapeutic agent for the treatment of cancer. Moreover, brusatol inhibited neurotoxicity induced by amyloid-β through activation of the Nrf2/HO-1 pathway, which resulted from inhibition of the PI3K/Akt/mTOR pathway, indicating the potential use of this agent in the treatment of gliomas.(236)
    Another major mechanism demonstrated for brusatol is its modulation of c-Myc. The c-Myc oncogene is a “master regulator” to control cellular growth and metabolism, a collection of metabolic pathways largely involved in energy production. c-Myc is overexpressed in the majority of human cancers to drive cell proliferation, to stimulate glycolysis, and to contribute to the development of some tumors, and thus, it has become an attractive cancer chemotherapeutic target.(237) Brusatol inhibited c-Myc expression in colorectal hypoxic cancer cells and mouse xenograft tumors, which induced hypoxia-inducing factor 1α (HIF-1α) degradation and cancer cell death,(238) and both brusatol and BRC down-regulated c-myc to induce leukemic cell differentiation and G1 arrest.(239) In addition, brusatol blocked potently the STAT3 signaling pathway in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) cells, and it was found to reduce the cell viability of human UD SCC2 HPV16-positive hypopharyngeal, JMAR floor-of-mouth squamous cell, and YD-10B oral squamous carcinoma cells, and induced apoptosis in these cells.(240) Furthermore, brusatol inhibited the cell growth of PaTu 8988 and Panc-1 human pancreatic cancer cells and induced apoptosis in these cells through the JNK (c-Jun N-terminal kinase)/p38 MAPK (mitogen-activated protein kinase)/NF-κB/STAT3/Bcl2 signaling pathway.(241)
    A further nonesterified analogue of BRC, bruceine D (9j), also has attracted interest for its antitumor potential. It was found to inhibit human breast and lung cancer cell growth and suppressed the viability, metastasis, and EMT of MDA-MB-231 human breast cancer cells.(242,243) Bruceine D (9j) induces mitochondria-dependent apoptosis and autophagy in A549 and NCI-H292 human lung cancer cells to inhibit cell growth,(243) and it exhibited potent cytotoxicity against Capan-1, Capan-2, Panc-1, and SW-1990 human pancreatic cancer cells.(244) In addition, bruceine D (9j) inhibits cell proliferation and migration and induced cell cycle arrest and apoptosis in osteosarcoma cells. It suppresses the sphere-forming and self-renewal ability of osteosarcoma stem cells, which could contribute to osteosarcoma relapse, metastasis, and resistance to chemotherapy.(245)
    In in vivo studies, the growth of A549 lung xenograft tumors was inhibited significantly when 4-week-old female BALB/c-nu mice were inoculated by A549 human lung cancer cells, which was followed by the occurrence of solid tumors, and then the tumor-bearing mice were treated (i.p.) with bruceine D (9j) (40 mg/kg, every 2 days) for 15 days. No significant toxicity observed in mice.(243) Bruceine D suppressed effectively pancreatic tumor growth without causing mortality or other obvious side effects when 5–7-week-old male athymic nu/nu mice were inoculated by Capan-2 human pancreatic cancer cells (1 week) and treated (i.p.) with this quassinoid (1.5 mg/kg, once daily) for 28 days.(244) Osteosarcoma growth was inhibited when four-week-old female BALB/c-nu mice were inoculated by MNNG/HOS human osteosarcoma cells (3 days) and treated (i.p.) with bruceine D (2.5 or 5 mg/kg, every alternate day) or cisplatin (2 mg/kg, twice a week) for 12 days. Neither discernible changes in body weights nor any pathological changes in the major organs of mice were observed. In addition, bruceine D (i.p., 5 mg/kg, every alternate day) showed more potent antiosteosarcoma activity than cisplatin (i.p., 2 mg/kg, twice a week) in a BALB/c-nu mouse MNNG/HOS xenograft osteosarcoma model.(245)
    Mechanistically, bruceine D induces A549 and NCI-H292 human lung cancer cell apoptosis and autophagy mainly through the activation of the ROS-mediated MAPK pathways,(243) and the bruceine D-induced Panc-1 cell apoptotic effects were dependent on the accumulated ROS and the inactivation of the PI3K/Akt signaling pathway.(244) Also, bruceine D inhibited MNNG/HOS human osteosarcoma stem cell growth through inhibition of STAT3, and it induced H460 and A549 NSCLC cell apoptosis by activation of the JNK pathway.(245,246) Accordingly, bruceine D may be a promising therapeutic lead compound candidate for the treatment of NSCLC, pancreatic cancer, and osteosarcoma.(243−246)
    A natural analogue of bruceine D (9j), ailanthone (9o) containing an ether bridge between C-11 and C-20, was found to be potently cytotoxic against Hep3B and HepG2 human hepatoma cells. The C-2–C-4 enone group, the Δ13(21) double bond, and the C-15 hydroxy group all seem to contribute positively to such activity, as indicated by natural products shinjulactone A (9p),(247) glaucarubolone (9q), and glaucarubol (9r).(214,248) In addition, the C-11/C-20 ether bridge appears critical for the activity observed, as exhibited by the natural analogue amarolide (9s), which did not show any growth inhibitory effects against Hep3B and HepG2 cells (Figure 21).(247)
    Ailanthone (9o) induced apoptosis in HL-60, KG1, OCI-AML2, THP-1, and U-937 human acute myeloid leukemia cells,(249) as well in MCF-7 human breast solid cancer cells,(250) and it inhibited the viability of SGC-7901 human gastric cancer cells(251) and induced G0/G1-phase cell cycle arrest to inhibit the proliferation of Huh7 human hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) cells.(252) The growth of liver tumors was inhibited significantly when 4–6-week-old male BALB/c nu/nu mice were inoculated by Huh7 cells (14 days) and treated (i.p.) with ailanthone (5 mg/kg, daily) for 16 days. No obvious toxicity was observed in mice, and decreased angiogenesis marker CD31 and p-VEGFR2 levels were observed in the tumors, indicating that ailanthone suppresses tumor growth in part by disrupting tumor vascularity.(252)
    Mechanistic studies have shown that ailanthone (9o) induces autophagy-mediated apoptosis through up-regulation of the expression of beclin-1 and LC3-II protein levels and down-regulation of the expression of LC3-I and p62 in HL-60 human leukemia cells.(253) It inhibited HL-60 cell growth, migration, and invasion through up-regulation of miR-449a and deactivation of the Notch and PI3K/Akt signaling pathways.(249) In addition, ailanthone induced MCF-7 and SGC-7901 cell apoptosis by upregulating Bax protein and mRNA,(250,251) and it decreased the expression levels of cyclins and CDKs while increasing the expression of p21 and p27 to induce cell cycle arrest in Huh7 cells, which was mitochondrially mediated and involved the PI3K/Akt signaling pathway.(252)
    Two synthetic derivatives of ailanthone, namely, SUN2071 (9t) and SUN0237 (9u), were found to show potent cytotoxicity toward L1210 murine leukemia cells, comparable to both BRC and vincristine. Leukemia development was inhibited, while the lifespan of tumor-bearing mice was increased significantly, when female C57BL/6 X DBA/2 mice were inoculated by P-388 or L1210 leukemia cells (1 day) and treated (i.p.) daily with SUN2071 (5 mg/kg), SUN0237 (5 mg/kg), or vincristine (0.25 mg/kg) for 9 days. The antileukemic effects of both SUN2071 and SUN0237 were similarly as potent as that of vincristine.(254) However, both the mechanism of action and the further development of these compounds have not been reported.
    Thus far, except for BRC, none of its simaroubolide analogues has been evaluated in cancer clinical trials, owing mainly to the fact that no objective cancer regressions observed in phase II clinical testing on BRC.(213,221) However, brusatol (9a), bruceine D (9j), and ailanthone (9o) all have shown potent antitumor activities in animal models, and thus they may have some type of clinical application, based on the mechanism of action involving the c-Myc and STAT3 proteins and the Notch pathway as reported for quassinoids.(216,217,219) In this regard, synthetic modifications, the introduction of conjugated drug units, and the development of novel drug delivery system for these compounds may be advantageous for future work.

    Dichapetalin A (DCT A, 10)

    Dichapetalin-type triterpenoids are a small group of 13,30-cyclo-dammarane-type tetracyclic triterpene lactones derived mainly from the plant family Dichapetalaceae, containing in common a phenethyl group linked through a pyran ring at the C-3, C-4, and C-29 positions, a C-17 five-membered lactone unit, a C-7 hydroxy group, and two Δ(2,3) and Δ(11,12) double bonds.(255) The first member of this group of NPs, dichapetalin A (DCT A, 10) was isolated originally in 1995 as a new constituent from the roots of Dichapetalum madagascariense Poir. (Dichapetalaceae) collected in Legon, Ghana (Figure 23).(256) The complete structure of DCT A was confirmed later by analysis of its single-crystal X-ray diffraction data, and the (4R,5R,7R,8R,9R,10S,13S,14S,17S,20S,23R,7′S) absolute configuration was determined by refining the Flack parameter [x = −0.1(0.3)].(257) Subsequently, additional dichapetalins were identified from this plant (D. madagascariense).(258)
    In the original investigation, DCT A (10) was found to show selectively potent cytotoxicity toward cancer cells, with the EC90 value being less than 0.17 nM when tested against L1210 murine leukemia cells.(256) Later, it was found also to be cytotoxic toward human HCT116 colon cancer and WM 266–4 melanoma cells, with EC50 values of 0.25 and 17 μM, respectively.(259) When tested against a small panel of human cancer cell lines, DCT A was found to show some selectivity. For example, it was potently active against SW626 human ovarian cancer cells (IC50 = 0.34 μM) but inactive toward BC1 human breast cancer cells (IC50 > 20 μM).(260) DCT A inhibited human CEM, HL-60, and Jurkat leukemia cell growth, with IC50 values in the range of 3.0–12 μM.(261) However, when tested in an in vivo hollow fiber assay, dichapetalin A (DCT A, 10) did not show evident inhibitory activity when 5–6-week-old female athymic NCr nu/nu mice were implanted with hollow fibers containing human LNCaP prostate, Lu1 lung, MCF-7 breast, or SW626 ovarian cancer cells and treated (i.p.) daily with DCT A (1, 2, 4, and 6 mg/kg) for 4 days.(260)
    Investigation of the cytotoxicity of DCT A and its analogues has indicated that changing the primary C-26 hydroxy group to an aldehyde [e.g., dichapetalin N (10a)] increases the cytotoxicity of DCT A against HCT116 and WM 266-4 cells.(259) Saturation of the Δ(11,12) double bond [e.g., dichapetalin L (10b)] results in the activity against human LNCaP prostate and Lu-1 lung cancer cells being enhanced slightly and that toward SW626 human ovarian cancer cells decreased greatly. However, addition of a water (H2O) molecule to the double bond between C-11 and C-12 [e.g., dichapetalin I (10c)] diminishes cytotoxicity against LNCaP and Lu-1 cells but potentiates the activity against SW626 cells (Figure 23),(259,260) indicating that the selectivity against cancer cells of DCT A may be enhanced by derivatization at the C-11 and C-12 positions. Surprisingly, when a hydroxy group was introduced at the C-22 position of DCT A (10) [e.g., dichapetalin B (10d)], cytotoxicity of 10 against both HCT116 and WM 266–4 cells was improved considerably,(259,260) implying that the C-22 position might be a key site for the modification of DCT A. In addition, substitution of a methoxy group at the C-4′ position [e.g., dichapetalin K (10e)] enhanced slightly the cytotoxic potency against LNCaP and Lu-1 cells but weakened substantially such an effect on SW626 cells, while further addition of a water molecule at the Δ(11,12) double bond [e.g., dichapetalin J (10f)] resulted in the potency against LNCaP and Lu-1 cells being decreased and that toward SW626 cells being enhanced (Figure 23).(260) Discovery of an inactive compound, songbodichapetalin (10g), containing a 3′,4′-methylenedioxy, a C-22 hydroxy, and a C-26 methoxy group, when evaluated against HT-29 human colon cancer cells, indicated that the substituents at all of the C-12, C-22, C-26, and C-7′ positions are important for 10 to mediate its cytotoxicity. As discussed previously in 2019, the presence of a primary C-26 hydroxy group seems important in determining the cytotoxic potency of the dichapetalin-type triterpenes.(13,262)
    Even though the C-17 lactone unit is important for the mediation of the cytotoxicity of DCT A, it is not essential, as indicated by DCT A derivatives that contain a C-17 hemiacetal rather than a lactone side chain, including 10h, dichapetalin O (10i), and dichapetalin Q (10j) (Figure 24). When the C-17 lactone unit of DCT A was reduced to a 21-hydroxytetrahydrofuran ring (e.g., 10h), the cytotoxicity against WM 266-4 cells was increased but that toward HCT116 cells was found to be decreased. Saturation of the Δ(11,12) double bond [e.g., dichapetalin O (10i)] reduced slightly the activity of 10h against both cell lines. However, the activity of 10i declined greatly when the 13,14,30-cyclopropane unit was opened followed by introduction of a Δ(13,14) double bond [e.g., dichapetalin Q (10j)], indicating that this cyclopropane ring plays a critical role in the determination of such an effect. In addition, the activity was not abolished when the C-17 tetrahydrofuran was replaced by a linear side chain or a tetrahydropyran ring, as shown by 10k, dichapetalin C (10l), and dichapetalin R (10m) (Figure 24),(259) suggesting that a cyclic substitution at the C-17 position of DCT A is not critical for mediation of its cytotoxicity.
    Several novel analogues of DCT A containing a spiroketal moiety formed by connecting C-23 and C-26 with an oxygen were found to be cytotoxic, of which dichapetalin S (10n) exhibited more potent activity than DCT A against WM 266–4 cells,(259) while the potency toward CEM and HL-60 cells was lessened when a hydroxy group is introduced to the C-22 position of 10n, followed by acetylation of its C-25 hydroxy group [e.g., 7-hydroxydichapetalin P (10o)].(261) The activity against these leukemia cells was potentiated when the C-25 acetoxy group of 10o is modified to a β-hydroxybutyrate unit [e.g., dichapetalin X (10p)],(261,263) and the potency toward HCT116 and WM 266-4 cells was improved greatly when the C-7 hydroxy group of 10o is changed to a carbonyl group [e.g., dichapetalin P (10q)]. Such an effect was further increased when a hydroxy group is introduced to the C-6 position of 10q [e.g., dichapetalin M (10r)] (Figure 25),(259,264) showing that a 6-hydroxy-7-carbonyl unit is required by spiro-DCTs to exhibit maximal cytotoxic potency.
    However, much less potent activity toward a small panel of human cancer cells was observed when the C-25 acetoxy group of 10r or its analogues was replaced by a 3-hydroxy-3-(4-hydroxyphenyl)propanoate unit [e.g., dichapetalin U (10s), dichapetalin V (10t), and dichapetalin W (10u)]. Substitution of a hydroxy group at the C-22 position of 10s (e.g., 10t) enhanced the activity slightly, but the switching of this hydroxy group to the C-24 position and removal of that at the C-3″ position followed by introduction of a methoxy group at the C-4′ position (e.g., 10u) resulted in activity being abolished (Figure 25).(265)
    These observations indicate that a C-25 hydroxy group is important, but a bulky ester substituent at the C-25 position may not be preferable for the mediation of cytotoxicity of the spiro-DCTs. Thus, the most potently cytotoxic DCT yet discovered is acutissimatriterpene E (10v), containing a satuated C-11 and C-12 bond and C-22 hydroxy, C-25 methoxy, and 3′,4′-methylenedioxy groups, which showed inhibitory activity against P-388 murine leukemia cell growth, with an IC50 value of 7.4 nM.(266) The preliminary SAR investigations as discussed above show that all of the substituents at the C-6, C-7, C-12, C-22–C-26, and C-7′ positions contribute to the cytotoxicity of DCTs, and the C-22 hydroxy group and the 6-hydroxy-7-carbonyl unit are preferred for this type of activity, indicating that the potential antitumor activity of DCTs could be improved by synthetic modifications at these positions. Introducing a hydroxy group at the C-22 position increases the cytotoxicity of 10, while changing the C-21 carbonyl group to a hydroxy group decreases such activity (Figure 26). Thus, the potently active compounds acutissimatriterpene E [10v, IC50 = 7.4 nM (P-388 cells)] and dichapetalin B [10d, IC50 = 81 nM (HCT116 cells)] could be modified by changing their C-7 hydroxy group to a 6-hydroxy-7-carbonyl unit, while the cytotoxicity of dichapetalin M [10r, IC50 = 9.9 nM (HCT116 cells)] may be enhanced by a change of the C-25 acetoxy group to a methoxy group.
    DCT A (10) and all of its analogues (10a–10v) discussed above are plant-derived triterpenoids, of which, except for DCT A, none of the other DCTs has thus far been tested for their potential antitumor activity in an animal model, and the mechanism of action of all of these compounds has not been determined. On the basis of the SAR conclusions obtained for DCTs, some derivatives showing more potent activity could be synthesized in future investigations on this type of triterpenoid. In addition, compounds 10d, 10r, and 10v all exhibit potent activities against certain cancer cells, and hence more detailed investigations seem advisable for their possible further development, including in vivo antineoplastic efficacy evaluation, molecular target determination, and novel drug delivery system preparation.

    Limonin (LMN 11)

    As reported in a 2014 review article, limonoids, a group of secondary metabolites confined to the families Rutaceae and Meliaceae, are modified euphane-type tetracyclic furanotetranortriterpenoids, with the loss of the terminal four carbon atoms (C-24–C-27), followed by cyclization of a furan ring, of which one of the four rings (A, B, C, or D) may be opened by oxidation.(267) The term “limonoid” is derived from limonin (LMN, 11), the first member of the limonoid group identified as the bitter constituent of the seeds of a Citrus species, for which the molecular structure was established by an X-ray crystallographic investigation,(268) and the (1S,5R,8R,9R,10R,13S,14R,15S,17S) absolute configuration was determined by application of the heavy-atom method and a full three-dimensional analysis of the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of epilimonol iodoacetate.(269) Limonin (LMN, 11) is a major component of the seeds of lemon [Citrus limon (L.) Osbek (Rutaceae)],(270) and it has been named previously as citrolimonin, dictamnolactone, evodin, and obaculactone.(271) Thus far, several other limonoids have been characterized from lemon seeds, including limonexic acid, isolimonexic acid, limonin glucoside, nomilin, obacunone, and obacunone glucoside (Figure 27).(272)
    Lemons are used widely as a Citrus crop of benefit to human health, and lemon-derived limonoids have been reported for their potential pharmaceutical properties, including antibacterial, antifungal, antimalarial, antineoplastic, and antiviral activities,(267) as a result of which LMN was found to show potential antitumor activity.(273) For example, LMN (11) inhibited human MCF-7 breast cancer and MDA-MB-435 melanoma cell proliferation, with its IC50 values being 4.3 and 26 μM, respectively,(274) and it also inhibited the growth of Panc-28 human pancreatic cancer cells (IC50 = 42 μM) (Figure 27).(275) Although LMN did not show any activity toward P-388 murine leukemia cells,(276) it was found to suppress hexokinase 2 (HK2) activity to inhibit tumor glycolysis in HCC cells, which induced cell apoptosis to inhibit cell proliferation.(277) Interestingly, LMN was recently found to attenuate the stemness of cancer cells, including breast cancer,(278) cervical cancer,(279) hepatoma,(280) and nasopharyngeal cancer stem cells.(281)
    The potential antitumor activity, toxicity, and pharmacokinetics of LMN have been summarized recently in 2019,(273) and discussed below is updated information to this previous review. In an vivo study, benzo(a)pyrene[B(a)P]-induced lung carcinogenesis was inhibited when C57BL/6J mice that weighed around 20–25 g were fed (twice a week) with B(a)P (50 mg/kg) for 4 weeks, followed by a six-week oral treatment with LMN (50 mg/kg).(282) Mechanistically, LMN inhibited HCC proliferation through the suppression of HK-2 activity, from which the glycolytic level in HCC cells was substantially reduced, and mitochondria-mediated apoptosis was induced by the resultant release of cytochrome c. A decrease of HK-2 phosphorylation was observed mainly due to the inhibition of Akt activity,(277) and thus LMN was found to attenuate the stemness of HCC cells through activating the PI3K/Akt signaling pathway.(280) In MCF-7 and MDA-MB-231 human breast cancer cells, LMN decreased MIR216A methylation levels and thus increased miR-216a-3p expression to inactivate the Wnt/β-catenin pathway, which resulted in attenuation of the stemness of these cancer cells (Figure 28).(278) In addition, LMN induced apoptosis in A549 human lung cancer cells by enhancing ROS production,(282) and it attenuated the stemness of HeLa cervical cancer cells and inhibited the progression of oral tongue squamous cell cancer cells via inhibiting YAP (Yes-associated protein, the root of cancer) transcriptional regulatory activity through promoting YAP nuclear-cytoplasmic translocation.(279,283)
    Recently, a zein-alginate encapsulation system to produce highly dispersible limonin nanoparticles has been developed. The release of LMN in simulated gastric fluid, and, preferentially, in simulated intestinal fluid, was delayed and minimized by this nanodelivery system. Simultaneously, this zein-alginate encapsulated LMN exhibited significantly improved glutathione S-transferase-inducing, free radical-scavenging, and antiangiogenic activity, indicating the potential of effective oral delivery system to enhance the bioavailability of LMN.(284) However, the relatively weak cytotoxic potency of LMN seems to limit its potential drug use, and thus, SAR-guided synthetic modification may facilitate the development of its modified derivatives as useful cancer chemotherapeutic agents.
    SAR investigations for different types of limonoids and their potential antitumor activity have been reviewed recently in 2018, and both the furan ring and substitution at the C-7 position were found to be required for LMN to induce phase II detoxification enzymes.(285) Inspection of the inhibitory activity toward Panc-28 human pancreatic cancer cells by LMN (11, IC50 = 42 μM), limonexic acid (11a, IC50 = 22 μM), isolimonexic acid (11b, IC50 = 18 μM), and limonin glucoside (11c, IC50 = 20 μM) (Figure 27)(275) showed that the natural products 11a–11c all exhibited comparable activities, with their potencies being somewhat greater than that of 11. These data indicate that changing the furan ring to a lactone unit or opening the six-membered δ-lactone unit followed by introducing a glucosyl moiety at the C-17 hydroxy group increases slightly the growth inhibitory activity of LMN against Panc-28 cells.
    However, when tested toward MCF-7 estrogen receptor-positive human breast cancer and MDA-MB-435 estrogen receptor-negative human breast cancer cells (revised later as MDA-MB-435 human melanoma cells), the respective proliferation inhibition of limonin glucoside (11c, IC50 = 55 and 119 μM) was found to be much less potent than that of LMN (11, IC50 = 4.3 and 26 μM),(274) demonstrating that opening the δ-lactone unit followed by C-17 glucosylation diminishes greatly the activity of LMN against these cancer cells. While the naturally occurring deoxylimonin (11d) exhibited an activity against MCF-7 cells (IC50 = 5.5 μM) that was comparable with LMN, its activity toward MDA-MB-435 cells (1.7 μM) was more pronounced than that of LMN (Figure 27),(274) leading to the conclusion that the C-14–C-15 epoxy group is not essential for LMN to mediate its cytotoxicity toward these cancer cell types.
    Interestingly, the activities of LMN toward both MCF-7 and MDA-MB-435 cells are enhanced more than 30 times when the C-1–C-5 bicyclic system is changed to a seven-membered lactone monocyclic unit [e.g., in the plant-derived nomilin (11e, IC50 = 0.097 and 0.78 μM against MCF-7 and MDA-MB-435 cells, respectively],(274) suggesting that the C-1–C-5 monocyclic ring is preferred for enhancing the activity of LMN. Also, deacetylation [e.g., deacetylnomilin (11f, IC50 = 0.01 μM)] or deacetoxylation [e.g., obacunone (11g, IC50 = 0.02 μM)] of nomilin resulted in the activity against MCF-7 cells being increased greatly,(274) indicating that the presence of a C-1 acetoxy group reduces the cytotoxic potency of nomilin. Obacunone glucoside (11h, IC50 = 3.2 μM) showed a much less potent activity than obacunone itself (11g, IC50 = 0.02 μM) (Figure 27) against MCF-7 cells,(274) demonstrating that the C-13–C-17 δ-lactone unit is required, but introduction of a glucosyl group may not be preferred for such an activity. In addition, all of the potently active compounds, 11e (IC50 = 0.097 and 0.78 μM), 11f (IC50 = 0.01 and 0.15 μM), and 11g (IC50 = 0.02 and 6.8 μM) in this series showed a greater sensitivity toward MCF-7 cells than against MDA-MB-435 cells, suggesting that these compounds could be useful in the design of selective anticancer agents.
    Of these analogues, nomilin (11e), isolated originally from lemon seeds, showed cell proliferation inhibitory activities against human breast cancer and melanoma cells,(270,274) and it has exhibited some promise in the inhibition of tumor metastasis and angiogenesis. Metastatic lung tumor nodule formation was inhibited when 6–8-week-old male C57BL/6 mice were inoculated by BI6F-10 melanoma cells followed by daily treatments (i.p.) with nomilin (6 mg/kg) for 10 days, followed by 11 days of the absence of the treatment.(286) Tumor-specific angiogenesis was suppressed significantly when 4–6-week-old male C57BL/6 mice were inoculated by B16F-10 melanoma cells, followed immediately with daily treatments (i.p.) with nomilin (6 mg/kg) for 5 days.(287)
    Obacunone (11g, IC50 = 0.02 μM) was found to be more active than nomilin (11e, IC50 0.097 μM) against the MCF-7 estrogen receptor-positive human breast cancer cell line in an early investigation.(274) However, its activity against SW480 colon and LNCaP human prostate cancer cells was much less potent, with IC50 values of 56 and around 12 μM, respectively (Figure 27),(288,289) with a lack of evident cytotoxicity (IC50 > 50 μM) observed when evaluated against MCF-7 cells.(290) Interestingly, obacunone was found to induce apoptosis in LNCaP and SW480 cells through activation of the intrinsic pathway.(288,289) It up-regulated the expression of Bax and down-regulated Bcl2 expression to induce apoptosis in MCF-7 cells, while it decreased the expression of NF-κB and COX-2 by activation of the MAPK signaling pathway, indicating its inhibitory effects on estrogen-responsive breast cancer through the inhibition of inflammatory pathways.(290)
    Gedunin (11i), an analogue of obacunone with the absence of an oxygen atom between C-3 and C-4, was isolated originally from the heartwood of Entandrophragma angolense (Welw.) C.DC. (Meliaceae) in 1960,(291) with the structure determined by analysis of the single-crystal X-ray data of dihydrogedun-3β-yl iodoacetate.(292) Gedunin (11i) was determined as being inactive against A549 human lung cancer cells,(293) while it exhibited moderate cytotoxicity toward human MCF-7 and SK-BR-3 breast cancer and HL-60 leukemia cells, with IC50 values in the range 3–9 μM (Figure 29).(293,294) Tumor incidence was inhibited completely when the right buccal pouches of two-month-old male Syrian hamsters were painted by 7,12-dimethylbenz[a]anthracene (DMBA), and the animals were treated (intragastrically) with gedunin (0.1 mg/kg, three times a week) for 14 weeks.(295)
    Mechanistically, gedunin inhibited the proliferation of PA-1 and OVCAR-3 human ovarian cancer cells through G2/M-phase arrest and ROS-mediated intrinsic apoptosis, which involved the MAPK and JAK/STAT3 pathways.(296) It induced apoptotic death of MCF-7, MDA-MB-231, T47D, and Hs578T human breast cancer cells through inactivation of the cochaperone p23 protein, from which its cellular interaction with Hsp90 is blocked,(297) and it prohibited the growth and metastasis of HPAC human pancreatic cancer cells through inhibition of sonic hedgehog signaling.(298) Administration of gedunin suppressed the development of hamster buccal pouch carcinomas by inhibiting the PI3K/Akt and NF-κB pathways, and it blocked angiogenesis by downregulating the expression of miR-21, VEGF, and HIF-1α.(295)
    Investigation of the cytotoxicity of gedunin (11i) and its analogues showed that deacetylation [e.g., 7-desacetylgedunin (11j)] decreased the activity against MCF-7 and SK-BR-3 human breast cancer cells, and introducing an additional epoxy group at the C-1 and C-2 position [e.g., 1,2-dihydro-7-desacetyl-1,2-epoxygedunin (11k)] resulted in the activity being abolished,(294) while changing C-7 acetyl to a benzoyl group [e.g., 7-deacetyl-7-benzoylgedunin (11l)] enhanced the activity against HL-60 cells slightly.(293) These observations suggest that the C-1–C-3 enone group seems critical in the mediation of the cytotoxicity of gedunin, and that activity can be improved by modifications at the C-7 position. Surprisingly, cleavage of the C-7 and C-8 bond and the oxygen-bridge between the C-1 and C-14 carbons resulted in the activity against IMR32 human neuroblastoma cells being enhanced substantially, as shown by cipaferen G (11m), which was potently cytotoxic against IMR cells, with an IC50 value of 22 nM (Figure 29).(299) Also, the cytotoxicity against HepG2 human hepatoma cells of cipaferen G (11m) was enhanced more than 10 000-fold, when a N-benzoylpiperazine unit was linked synthetically to its acetyl group [e.g., 11n, IC50 = 0.01 μM (HepG2 cells)]. Both 11m and 11n showed some selectivity among the cancer cells tested,(299) and thus, they seem to be promising lead compounds for further investigation.
    Furthermore, removal of the oxygen atom between C-16 and C-17 of gedunin leads to the azadirone-type limonoids, of which nimbolide (11o), containing a 6,28-lactone unit, a C-7 and C-15 oxygen-bridged tetrahydrofuran ring, and a cleaved C-12 and C-13 bond (Figure 30), is an important limonoid member that shows potential antitumor properties. Nimbolide (11o) was isolated originally from the fresh leaves of the neem tree [Azadirachta indica A. Juss. (Meliaceae)] in 1967,(300) with the structure determined by analysis of its single-crystal X-ray diffraction data.(301) On the basis of prior literature reports in 2014 and 2016, this limonoid affects tumor cell proliferation and apoptosis and tumor angiogenesis and metastasis through different mechanisms.(302,303) Nimbolide (11o) was found to be potently cytotoxic against P-388 murine leukemia cells (IC50 = 0.14 μM), while it showed a lower potency toward other cancer cell lines (IC50 = 0.43–1.3 μM),(304) with a moderate activity observed also against the MCF-7 (IC50 = 4.0 μM) and MDA-MB-231 (IC50 = 6.0 μM) human breast cancer cell lines (Figure 30).(305) Also, nimbolide induces cancer cell apoptosis,(305) and its apoptotic effects were found selectively for cancer cell lines but not for normal cells.(306) Importantly, it induced mitochondrial apoptosis in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma cells, with the potency being greater than that of gemcitabine, the first-line agent to treat pancreatic cancer, and other agents, including sorafenib and curcumin.(307)
    In in vivo investigations, nimbolide (11o) showed positive results. Colon tumor growth was inhibited when four-week-old athymic nu/nu mice were inoculated by HCT116 human colon cancer cells (1 week) and treated (i.p.) daily with nimbolide (5 mg/kg) for 10 days.(308) Also, liver tumor growth was retarded when five-week-old male BALB/c nude mice were inoculated by Huh7 human liver cancer cells (12 days) and treated (orally) three times per week with nimbolide (10 mg/kg) for 5 weeks.(309) Moreover, the growth of oral tumors was delayed significantly when the right buccal pouches of eight-ten-week-old male Syrian hamsters were painted with DMBA, and the animals were treated (i.g.) daily with nimbolide (0.1 mg/kg) for 4 weeks.(310)
    Nimbolide (11o) targets different signaling pathways to mediate its antitumor effects. It induced mitochondrial apoptosis in Huh-7 HCC cells through activation of the MAPK pathway, which involves activating the inhibition of c-IAP1 (c-inhibitor of apoptosis 1) expression.(309) It activated autophagy-mediated apoptotic cell death in MDA-MB-231 and MCF-7 breast cancer cells, for which apoptosis signaling was induced via downregulation of Bcl-2 proteins and activation of caspases, with the autophagy signaling being activated by increasing Beclin 1 and LC3B (MAP1-LC3B, microtubule-associated protein 1 light chain 3), along with decreased p62 and mTOR protein expression that resulted from inhibition of HDAC-2.(311) Also, nimbolide induced initially autophagy leading to apoptosis in SCC131 and SCC4 human oral cancer cells, which resulted in inhibition of cell growth. The decreased expression of LC-3 II, Beclin-1, and autophagy related 5 (ATG5), which function as molecular links between autophagy and apoptosis, and the enhanced expression of Bax, cytosolic cytochrome c, and cleaved caspase-3 indicated a cytoprotective effect of the autophagy induced by nimbolide. Moreover, nimbolide mediates autophagy-dependent apoptosis via downregulation of homeobox transcript antisense intergenic RNA (HOTAIR), a competing endogenous RNA that sponges miR-126, an activator of GSK (glycogen synthase kinase)-3β. This may increase the expression of miR-126 leading to activation of GSK-3β to contribute to inactivation of PI3K/Akt/GSK3 signaling by nimbolide.(310) In addition, nimbolide (11o) inhibited the proliferation and invasion of HCT116 human colon cancer cells through inhibition of NF-κB activation.(308)
    Concurrent regulation of autophagy, an evolutionarily conserved form of programmed cell death, and apoptosis is desired to improve cancer chemotherapeutic outcomes through retarding cancer cell MDR. Thus, nimbolide (11o) was proposed as being worthy of evaluation for its safety and efficacy in cancer clinical testing, based on its potent autophagy/apoptosis-targeted antitumor efficacy.(308,310) This was supported by a pharmacokinetic investigation reported recently, when male Sprague–Dawley rats were administered i.v. (10 mg/kg) or orally (10, 30, and 50 mg/kg) by nimbolide, with the blood samples of rats being collected through the retro-orbital sinus at different time points and tested using the LC/QTOF/MS method. The maximum plasma concentrations of nimbolide were determined as around 15.3 and 5555.2 ng/mL at 10 mg/kg by oral and i.v. administration, respectively, which indicated a poor oral absorption that may delay the therapeutic translation of this compound.(312) Thus, structural optimization followed by novel delivery system development for nimbolide seems to be required for the development of promising antitumor candidate.(312)
    Nimbolide (11o) showed more potent activity than 28-deoxonimbolide (11p) against Col-2 and HCT15 human colon cancer and P-388 murine leukemia cells (Figure 30),(304) indicating that the C-6/C-28 oxygen-bridged lactone unit is important in the modulation of its cytotoxicity. A greatly enhanced cytotoxic potency toward murine P-388 cells was observed when the lactone unit of 11o is replaced by a tetrahydropyran ring composed of C-4, C-5, C-10, C-19, and C-28, with its oxygen-bridged C-7 and C-15 tetrahydrofuran ring modified to a 14,15-epoxy group followed by a direct connection of C-12 and C-13 [e.g., amoorastatin (11q)].(313) The natural product 11q exhibited potent activity against P-388 cells, with the IC50 value being less than 1.9 nM,(313) but its close natural analogue, amoorastatone (11r), containing a C-15 carbonyl group, was found to be inactive (IC50 = 58 μM),(314) indicating that the 14,15-epoxy group is critically important for amoorastatin (11q) to mediate its activity against P-388 cells. The activity of 11q did not change greatly when a hydroxy group was substituted at the C-12 position [e.g., 12-hydroxyamoorastatin (11s)], but the activity against SK-MEL-2 human melanoma cells of 11s was enhanced more than 10-fold when its 12-hydroxy group was acetylated [e.g., 12-acetoxyamoorastatin (11t, IC50 = 1.2 nM].(314,315) Further acetylation of the C-28 hydroxy group of 11t [e.g., sendanin (11u)] did not increase the activity, but changing the 14,15-epoxy group of 11s to a carbonyl group [e.g., 12-hydroxyamoorastatone (11v)] decreased the potency greatly (Figure 30),(314,315) suggesting that both the 3,12-diacetyl and 14,15-epoxy groups are required in order for 12-acetoxyamoorastatin (11t) to mediate its cancer cell cytotoxicity, and that its activity might be improved by further modifications at the C-12 position. Thus, additional work could be focused on detailed investigations on the in vivo antitumor efficacy and mechanism of action of this limonoid (11t) for the discovery of a possible autophagy-targeted antitumor agent.
    Limonin (LMN, 11) is a major component of the seeds of lemon and other Citrus species and shows a broad spectrum of bioactivities of potential benefit to human health. Numerous naturally occurring limonoids that represent different skeletons and related to limonin (11) have thus far characterized. Of these compounds, nomilin (11e), obacunone (11g), gedunin (11i), nimbolide (11o), and LMN (11) itself have attracted wide attention due to their potential antitumor activities, and 11o was found to target autophagy/apoptosis to mediate its antitumor property. However, except for compound 11n, all of the other analogues of LMN (11) are plant-derived natural products, and thus, synthetic modifications of these compounds could be performed in future investigations. SAR investigations for limonin (LMN, 11) and its analogues as discussed above indicate that changing C-1–C-5, C-10, and C-19 bicyclic system to a monolactone unit enhanced cytotoxicity of 11 (Figure 31). Thus, the antitumor activity of limonoids may be enhanced greatly when a tetrahydropyran ring is introduced to a gedunin-type molecule with C-1 and C-14 bridged by an oxygen atom, or to an azadirone-type limonoid containing oxygen-linked to the C-19 and C-28 carbons, as represented by 11n and 11t, respectively. Accordingly, these potent antitumor leads could be investigated further to develop autophagy-targeted agents to combat MDR in cancer.

    Summary and Outlook

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In this Perspective, 11 antitumor terpenoid lactones (1–11, Table 1), along with over 100 of their analogues, representing plant-derived sesquiterpene, diterpene, and triterpene lactones and their derivatives, have been reviewed for their potential antineoplastic activity, with SAR information, mechanisms of action, and clinical possibilities highlighted. Among them, ART (1), PTL (2), AGL (4), and BRC (9), along with the prodrugs, mipsagargin (3b) and Minnelide (8h) of TPG (3) and TPL (8), respectively, have been evaluated in cancer clinical trials. The structures of these compounds may be used as valuable scaffolds for the design and development of novel agents for the effective treatment of cancer.
    The complete structures of compounds 1–11 have been determined by either analysis of their single-crystal X-ray diffraction data or by total synthesis of these molecules or their related derivatives, and these determinations have been supported in many cases by further analysis of their electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectra. This structural information will be critically important for the possible further development of these compounds as anticancer agents.
    Sesquiterpene lactones (SQLs) are a large group of natural products, with many members being found to show potential antitumor activity.(11) SQLs 1–3 presented herein, have been evaluated in cancer clinical trials, of which derivatives of ART (1) are used clinically to treat malaria, and PTL (2) and TPG (3) are potent inhibitors of NF-κB and SERCA, respectively. Some other SQLs, including arglabin, micheliolide, and α-santonin that show potential antitumor activity, have been summarized previously(316−318) and so are not included in the present Perspective.
    The α,β-unsaturated γ-lactone moiety has been defined as important for SQLs to show cancer cell cytotoxicity.(319) However, the importance of a lactone unit in the mediation of cytotoxicity of the terpenoid lactones 1–9 has not been demonstrated definitively thus far, and this unit seems not critical in the exhibition of cytotoxicity by analogues of dichapetalin A (DCT, 10) and limonin (LMN, 11). For example, all of the compounds 10h–10m exhibited cytotoxicity against WM 266–4 human melanoma cells, at comparable levels to that of dichapetalin A (DCT, 10) (Figures 23 and 24).(259) In turn, nimbolide (11o) showed less potent activity than amoorastatin (11q) toward P-388 murine leukemia cells (Figure 30).(304,313) Thus, additional synthetic modifications focused on the lactone unit of compounds 1–11 could be performed in future investigations.
    The potential antitumor activity of dihydroartemisinin (DHA, 1a) has been improved when compared with that of artemisinin (ART, 1),(15,27) and a water-soluble amino derivative of parthenolide (PTL, 2), dimethylaminoparthenolide (DMAPT or LC-1, 2c), was found to show potent cytotoxicity against AML cells.(46) In addition, Minnelide (8h), a water-soluble prodrug of triptolide (TPL, 8) and a 14-O-phosphonooxymethyltriptolide disodium salt, has been developed as a promising agent evaluated in cancer clinical trials.(171,199) These successful examples indicate that the terpenoid lactones (1–11) could be modified at their lactone unit, through reduction of the carbonyl group, followed by introduction of a dimethylamino or a phosphonooxymethyl group. Such modifications may be supportive of the development of novel anticancer agents from terpenoid lactones.
    The pharmacophores of the terpenoid lactones discussed have been characterized by SAR investigations, and the isoprenoid core, the enone and lactone units, and the oxygen-bridged multiple ring systems have been found to be important for the mediation of the antitumor properties of compounds 1–11. Following the SAR conclusions made, a number of derivatives that display improved antitumor potencies have been prepared, which indicate that acetylation, dimerization, and introduction of an α-hydroxy-substituted carbonyl group, an enone or related longer conjugated system, an epoxy group, a lactone unit, a pyran ring, or a drug conjugate, may enhance the potential antitumor activity of a terpenoid lactone. These observations should be supportive of the design and development of future natural product anticancer agents of this type. However, it is worth noting that most SAR conclusions that have been discussed in the present contribution are based on relatively limited numbers of the natural product analogues or their synthetic derivatives. Thus, an enlarged number of the analogues of these lead compounds should be investigated in the future to support or to modify the SAR conclusions made herein.
    To overcome factors that have limited antitumor efficacy of the compounds presented, including undesired toxicity and poor bioavailability observed in preclinical investigations, synthetic modifications, including introducing water-soluble moieties and drug conjugation or hybrid molecule formation have been carried out for several of the examples discussed. Overall, the modified products obtained have shown an improved antitumor potential when compared with their parent compounds. In addition, novel drug delivery systems developed for several of the compounds discussed were found to enhance their aqueous solubility and bioavailability, while other formulations have been designed to deliver the active compounds to tumor tissues directly to kill the malignant cells more effectively. These scientific accomplishments form a firm foundation for the further development of the lactones based on terpenoid scaffolds as new cancer chemotherapeutic agents.
    Cancer is a genetic disease, with multiple complex biological processes involved. The occurrence of a mutator phenotype in cancer cells indicates the possibility of the development of adaptive resistance in tumors, and thus, it may be rationalized that the design of further effective anticancer drugs should focus on compounds with multiple rather than single molecular targets. In this regard, mechanism-based anticancer drug discovery seems highly desirable. As discussed in this perspective article, terpenoid lactones can be quite structurally complex, and they have been shown to interact with diverse molecular targets to mediate their potential antitumor activity. These include the major targets of AR for ART (1), NF-κB for PTL (2), SERCA for TPG (3), COX2 for AGL (4), PAFR for GKL B (5), HK2 for JKL B (6), RIOK2 for NGL E (7), Hsp70 for TPL (8), c-Myc for BRC (9), and YAP for LMN (11) (Table 1). These targets and their triggered signaling pathways control cancer cell proliferation, invasion, and migration, MDR against chemotherapeutic treatments, and tumor growth by interfering with cancer cell autophagy, apoptosis, necrosis, and cancer stem cell proliferation, as well as interacting with the tumor genomes, the inflammatory response, the microenvironment, cellular metabolism, and immune destruction.
    Indeed, several of the compounds discussed herein have attracted attention for their antitumor properties as a result of their activity against the molecular targets rather than their growth inhibitory potency toward cancer cells. For example, thapsigargin (TPG, 3) was found to inhibit SERCA (IC50 = 3.9 nM) to increase Ca2+ levels in the cytoplasm of cancer cells,(68,69) which led to the development of the prodrug mipsagargin (3b, G-202) that was evaluated in phase I and II cancer clinical trials.(62,82,83) Ginkgolide B (GKL B, 6) was identified as a specific PAF inhibitor that induces tumor cell apoptosis, and thus the antiovarian tumor efficacy of cisplatin was found to be improved by combination treatment of this drug with GKL B.(116) These results indicate that mechanism-targeted discovery of anticancer agents is promising, and those novel bitarget cancer drug conjugates could be preferential candidates in this regard.
    Moreover, several compounds presented, including ART (1), TPG (3), TPL (8), bruceine D (9j), and nimbolide (11o), showed autophagy modulatory activity. Autophagy is a naturally regulated cellular mechanism for the control of important physiological functions, and it contributes to cancer as both a tumor survival promoter and suppressor. There is crosstalk between autophagy and apoptosis through several signaling pathways, which could contribute to the reversal of the cancer MDR.(1) Thus, compounds modulating autophagy could improve current cancer chemotherapy by decreasing MDR effects.
    In addition, cancers are also complex matrices composed of malignant and nonmalignant cells, which together create a tumor microenvironment (TME). Communication between the stroma and malignant cells enables cancer cells to invade normal adjacent tissues, and interaction with the TME contribute critically to the successful treatment of cancer.(1,320) As discussed in the present perspective, several TME-related targets, including autophagy, cancer stem cells, PI3K/Akt/mTOR, HIF-1α, HK2, and Wnt2, have been reported as the cellular signaling mechanisms of 1–11. Thus, it could be a promising strategy to design and discover some TME-targeted anticancer agents based on the terpenoid lactones, 1–11.
    Frequently, the genotoxicity of any anticancer agents may prevent their development toward clinical trial investigations. Of the lead compounds discussed, three SQLs, ART (1), PTL (2), and TPG (3), a diterpene [TPL (8)], and a triterpene [LMN (11)] lactone have been reported for their potential genotoxicity.(186,321,322) However, no genotoxic effects have been demonstrated for compounds 4–7, 9, and 10 to date. Thus, more detailed information about potential mutagenic or immunogenic adverse effects of these terpenoid lactones could be reported in future investigations, and this will probably lead to the discovery of some novel terpenoid lactone derivative, with decreased genotoxic potency.
    Historically, plants are known to produce complex specialized metabolite organic compounds with the desired structural diversity to potentially interact with multiple cellular targets, and plant-derived natural products have played a key role in the discovery of new anticancer agents over the last several decades.(5,323−325) Further searches for plant-derived lead compounds as new antineoplastic agents could lead to the characterization of additional interesting compounds based on new structural types. These novel molecules may act on cancer cells through unusual mechanisms to afford possible new approaches for cancer treatment. In this context, the discovery of novel plant-derived terpenoid lactones and their derivatives may be of great importance. It is hoped that the information provided in the present contribution will be supportive of further work being performed on the discovery of antitumor agents from terpenoid lactones purified from higher plants.

    The authors declare no competing financial interest.

      adrenocortical carcinoma

      ADP

      adenosine diphosphate

      ADT

      androgen deprivation therapy

      AGL

      andrographolide

      Akt or PKB

      protein kinase B

      ALL

      acute lymphocytic leukemia

      acute myeloid leukemia

      AOM

      azoxymethane
